texts.es: La señora Maria de Jesús C. A. habita en el barrio Laureles Norte, barrio ubicado en la capital de Managua, tiene 46 años de edad, se encuentra soltera, tiene tres hijos los cuales trabajan. Actualmente la señora Maria de Jesús quien se dedica a la venta de café y pan, que lo inicio hace 25 años con la ayuda de sus hijos recogieron para iniciar el negocio; así mismo lo  empezó con mucha dificultad ya que no tenia un establecimiento para la venta de café y pan, pero en la actualidad cuenta con un tramo en el mercado mayoreo y eso le ha ayudado para obtener mas ventas. La señora Maria de Jesús solicita la cantidad de  C$  15,000   aun plazo de 12 meses para mejorar su casa, ya que requiere cambiar el techo de su casa, también en un futuro desea seguir mejorando su casa y su negocio para así poder apoyar económicamente  a su familia.
texts.en:
Señora Maria de Jesús C. A. lives in the neighborhood Laureles Norte, a neighborhood located in the capital of Managua. She is 46 years old, single, and has three children who work. Presently Señora Maria de Jesús is dedicated to selling coffee and bread, which she began doing 25 years ago with the help of her children to begin the business; the business started with much difficulty since she did not have an establishment for selling her coffee and bread, but now she works with a space in the major market and that has helped her obtain more sails. Señora Maria de Jesús is requesting a loan for the quantity of C$ 15,000 (Córdoba, the currency of Nicaragua), which she will pay back in 12 months, to improve her house, because it requires a new roof. Also in the future she wants to continue improving her house and her business in order to be able to economically support her family.

Translated from Spanish by Jay Osborne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Mend the roof of her house.

loans.name: Olga Maria

texts.es: La señora Olga Maria R. Cortéz habita en el barrio América uno, barrio ubicado en la capital de Managua, tiene 55  años de edad, se encuentra soltera, vive  con sus tres hijos de 20,25 y 30 años de edad, los cuales están trabajando. Actualmente la señora Olga se desempeña como enfermera del centro de salud de Tipitapa, tiene 6 meses de estar trabajando para este centro, donde en un futuro desea poder encontrar un mejor empleo donde pueda ganar un mejor salario, para seguir apoyando a su familia y a darle una mejor estabilidad económica, por tanto la señora Olga desea seguir trabajando con micro créditos de manera que poco a poco pueda ir mejorando la casa donde ella habita, ya que  por el momento requiere de un financiamiento de C$ 10,000 aun plazo de 12 meses para cambiar el techo de su casa.
texts.en:
Señora Olga Maria R. Cortéz lives in the neighborhood América, located in the capital of Managua. She is 55 years of age, single, and lives with her three children, who are 20, 25, and 30 years of age and all working. Presently Señora Olga is working as a nurse at the health center in Tipitapa; she has been working for six months in this center, where in the future she desires to be able to come across a better job in which she can earn a better salary to continue supporting her family and giving them better economic stability. Señora Olga wants to continue working with micro loans so that little by little she can go about improving the house where she lives, and at the moment she requires financing for C$ 10,000 (Córdoba, currency of Nicaragua) to fix her roof, which she will pay back in twelve months.

Translated from Spanish by Jay Osborne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Change the roof of her house.

loans.name: Oscar Moises

texts.es: El señor Oscar Moisés Ampie tiene la edad de 28 años habita en el sector de Denis Larios ubicado en municipio de Ticuantepe junto a su esposa y su hijo, la señora no trabaja es ama de casa por problemas de salud de su hijo, este señor trabaja en Lacayo Fiallos como albañil hace seis años, Don Ampie tiene el sueño de ver terminada su casa para darle una mejor condición de vida a su familia por lo cual solicita un monto de C$ 8,000.00 córdobas para comprar materiales de construcción.
texts.en:
Señor Oscar Moisés Ampie is age 28 and lives in the neighborhood Denis Larios located in the town of Ticuantepe together with his wife and his son. His wife does not work; she is a stay-at-home mother due to health problems of their son. Oscar works in Lacayo Fiallos as a mason and has been for six years. His dream is to see his house finished so he can provide better living conditions for his family. This is why he is requesting a loan in the amount of C$ 8,000 (Córdoboa, the currency of Nicaragua) to be able to buy construction materials.

Translated from Spanish by Jay Osborne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy construction materials.

loans.name: Nelsa Abigail

texts.es: La señora Nelsa Abigail M., tiene la edad de 58 años de edad habita en el barrio Esquí pula ubicado cerca de la iglesia católica, esta señora es soltera no tiene hijos pero tiene a su cargo a su papá y a un sobrino que su hermana le dejo a su cargo ya que falleció hace mucho tiempo, el joven de 14 años  después que llega de clases le ayuda con el negocio ya que ella le entrega y vende comida desde hace cinco años , los sueños de esta señora es llegar a tener un comedor . Ella solicita la cantidad de  C$ 6,000.00 córdobas para comprar  más insumos y granos básicos, ya que ahora la buscaron para entregar comida a la iglesia de Ticuantepe al personal que labora en la tienda, y ella no cuenta con muchos recursos para poder cumplir con sus encargos.
texts.en:
Señora Nelsa Abigail M. is 58 years of age and lives in the neighborhood Esquípula located near the catholic church. This lady is single and does not have any children, but she is in charge of caring for her father and a nephew who her sister left to her when she passed away a long time ago. The young boy is fourteen years old. After he arrives home from classes, he helps her with the business. She has been delivering and selling food for five years now. This lady's dream is to someday have a dining room for her business. She is requesting a loan for the quantity of C$ 6,000 (Córdobas, the currency of Nicaragua) to buy more ingredients and basic grains; now people have come to her to request food deliveries to the church of Ticuantepe for the people working in the store, and she does not currently work with the resources to be able to fulfill these orders.

Translated from Spanish by Jay Osborne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy primary ingredients and invest in her food business.

loans.name: Damaris Azucena

texts.es: La señora Damaris Azucena tiene la edad de 34 años habita en San Antonio Sur, es casada, su marido le ayuda con los gastos de la casa ya que tienen a su cargo 3 hijos, la señora Damaris trabaja como conserje en sporting club desde hace dos años, su sueños es tener mejor condición de vida  ya que viven en cuarto muy pequeños y quieren agrandarlo un poco, por lo cual ella nos solicita un C$ 6,000.00 córdobas para comprar materiales de construcción.
texts.en:
Ms. Damaris Azucena C. is 34 years old and lives in San Antonio Sur. She is married, and her husband helps her with the household expenses because they have to look after 3 children. Ms. Damaris has been working as a receptionist in a sporting club for three years. She dreams of having better living conditions because she and her family live in a very small room, and they want to expand it a little, which is why she is requesting C$ 6,000.00 Nicaraguan córdobas in order to purchase construction materials.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase construction materials for room improvements

loans.name: Digna Rosa

texts.es: La señora Digna Pérez M. tiene la edad de 30 años de edad, habita en el Km. 11 ½ carretera a Masaya, Esquí pula, junto con su marido Matin, este señor le ayuda con los gastos de casa, el labora como albañil, tienen dos hijas una niña de diez años y otra de un. Los sueños de doña Digna es darle mejor condición de vida, ella trabaja como ama de llave desde hace dos años para una casa privada, con mucho esfuerzo a logrado hacer gran parte de la vivienda, ella solicito el apoyo de AFODENIC ya que le recomendaron nuestra institución, esta señora solicito el monto de C$ 6,000.00 para compra de materiales de construcción. Y así poder logar tener una vida mejor junto a toda su familia.
texts.en:
Ms. Digna Pérez M. is 30-years-old, and lives in the Km. 11 ½ highway to Masaya, Corner of Pula, along with her husband Matin, who also helps with the expenses of the home. Mr. Matin is a construction worker. The couple has two daughters; a ten-year-old girl and a one year-old. Mrs Pérez’s dream is to give her daughters a better lifestyle, and to do so for the last two years she has worked as a nanny for a private family. With a lot of effort Mr. and Mrs. Pérez have managed to build most of their new house. Mr. Pérez is requesting the support of AFODENIC since they recommended our organization. Mrs. Pérez is requesting a loan for C$ 6.000,00 to purchase construction materials to finish their home, and thus to be able to have a better life next to her family.

Translated from Spanish by Antonella Sacconi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase construction materials

loans.name: Ban

texts.en: Ban N., 48, is married and lives with three of her children in the Kampong Cham, Cambodia. Since 2000, she has worked together with her husband on their farmland, growing rice and vegetables. They earn a combined US$6 each day and are aided by one child who works selling groceries from her home. Ban N. is asking for a loan of US$700 to add to their grocery inventory for her children. (Ban N.'s daughter is pictured)

loans.use: To add to their grocery inventory.

loans.name: Nut

texts.en:
Mr. Nut S. R. is 27 years old, and is single. He lives in Siem Reap province with his parents. He is an electrical repair man, and repairs televisions, radios, cassette and video players. He received training as an electrical repair man in school, and once he finished school he decided to open an electrical repair shop in his area. He opened the shop because he noticed that there were no such shops in the area where he lived. He earns on average about $7 per day. His mother is a food vendor and sells rice and a variety of Khmer dishes at the market. His father is a motor-taxi driver. Mr. Nut S. R. contributes his income to the total household income of his parents. On average, monthly expenses run about $82 with about $37 for food, $20 for utilities, and $25 for transportation. Inflation has hit Cambodia though, at a rate of about 22% from when the last statistics were taken, increasing monthly expenses for many people in Cambodia.

Mr. Nut S. R. is requesting his loan through Kiva’s field partner CREDIT – Micro Finance Institution. CREDIT-MFI has a repayment rate of 99.8% (taken from their 2007 Annual report). CREDIT – MFI structures their non-agriculture Kiva loans with a declining balance interest rate.  Agriculture loans are structured as balloon repayments with monthly interest rate payments and principle repayments at the end of the loan after harvest.

loans.use: To buy a new, more reliable moto-taxi for his father

loans.name: Kosal's Group

texts.en:
This loan is for a small group of three people. The leader of the group is Mrs. Kosal S., who is 30 years old and widowed. She has been selling dessert in her village since 2004, earning around $4 per day. Kosal has two children, both of whom are young and in school. She needs a loan of $150 to repair her stove so she can make her desserts to sell. 

The other members of her group are:
1- Mrs. Rao Y., a fish seller who needs a loan of $150 to purchase more fish to sell
2- Mrs. Khan K., a vegetable seller who needs a loan of $100 to purchase more vegetable to sell. 
All three members of this group live in Svay Chrum Village, Battambang Province.

loans.use: To repair her stove

loans.name: Pal

texts.en:
Pal K. S., 52, is a true entrepreneur, who lives with one child in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She has a business selling rice noodles, or in Cambodia language “Nom Banchok”. It is one of the favorite foods among Cambodian people. Rice noodles are served with many kinds of vegetables such as: mint, banana blossoms, string beans, English cucumber, mung bean sprouts, and other vegetables. Moreover, there are two types of soup for it:  green and red soup. Green soup is cooked with boneless fish only, and called in Cambodian language “Nom Banchok Samlah Khmer”. The other soup can be cooked with pork or chicken, and is called “Nom Banchok Namya”.

On average, she makes $1.50 of profit per day. Her husband is a motor-taxi and is able to make $2 as well.
Mrs. Pal K. S. would like a loan from Kiva of US$1000 to grow yams for extra profit. She sees this as a good opportunity to better their standard of living.

loans.use: To grow yams.

loans.name: Keo

texts.en: Keo A., 45, is married and lives with two of her children in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She grows beans and typically makes about US$5 per day, while her husband has a business operating a motor-taxi around the market in the village. On average, he earns US$5 per day as well. Two of their children are employed as construction workers. Keo A. would like to take out a loan of US$1000 to purchase bean seeds to grow.

loans.use: To purchase bean seeds.

loans.name: Moa

texts.en: Mrs. Moa M., a 30-year-old widow without any children, resides in Preak Thom Village in Kandal Province where she is a garment factory worker. Living alone in an  old house, she is requesting a loan to add to her savings to hire construction workers to build her a new house in order to live in better conditions.

loans.use: To add to her savings to hire construction workers to build her a new house.

loans.name: Ros

texts.en:
Mrs. Ros B., born in 1963, lives in Preak Thom Village in Kandal Province where she owns a small restaurant selling food to villagers and visitors. Her husband, Mr. Suos Muny, is a construction worker who makes a small income that helps support his family. Since his workplace is far from home, he also spends a great deal on transportation. In order to reduce these expenses, Ros is requesting a loan to add to her savings to buy a motorbike for her husband to travel to work.

Ros has six children, four of whom are blacksmiths while the remaining two are attending the local school. Her husband is shown on the right in the picture.

loans.use: To add to her savings to buy a motorbike for her husband to travel to work.

loans.name: Khoem

texts.en:
Mrs. Kjoem L., a resident of Preak Thom Village in Kandal Province, is a fruit seller in the local market. Since her business is doing well, she is requesting a loan to buy more fruit in order to meet customer demand.

Khoem is a 52-year-old widow with three children, two of whom are construction workers while the remaining one is attending the local school.

loans.use: To buy more fruit in order to meet customer demand.

loans.name: Horn

texts.en: Horn L., 36, is married and lives with five of her children in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She is a farmer who works growing yams to earn a living and is able to make about US$3 each day, while her husband is employed as a worker and makes US$5 per day as well. Horn L. would like to take out a loan of US$500 to hire a worker to cut the grass and then she can grow more yams.

loans.use: To grow yams.

loans.name: Morn

texts.en: Morn R., 48, lives in Kampong Cham province, about 124 miles from Phnom Penh, in Cambodia. She is married and has had a business selling groceries since 1990. She is able to make about US$2 per day, while her husband works selling firewood and makes US$3 a day. This couple together has three childR., one of whom is married and no longer stays at home. One child is a garment factory worker and the other one stays at home. Morn R. would like to take out a loan of US$1000 to make two investments. Firstly, she will use US$500 to diversify her grocery inventory, and secondly, she will use the rest to raise pigs for sale to provide her with extra profit.

loans.use: To add grocery items and to raise pigs.

loans.name: Yann

texts.en: Yann H., 37, lives with his wife and four children in Kampong Cham, Cambodia. To raise the family, he works as a worker, breaking rock. On average, he makes about US$6 each day. His wife, Sorn Sout, 39, is a farmer who has grown yams since 2005 to earn a living and is able to make US$5 per day to support the family. Mr. Yann H. would like to take out a loan of US$1000 to purchase yams in bulk for sale. He and his wife will slice and then dry them under the sunshine. (Husband is pictured)

loans.use: To purchase yams in bulk for sale.

loans.name: Farah's Group

texts.en:
Farah baji is the wife of Mr. P. and lives in a small area named Bund Road of City Lahore, Pakistan. She has been married for the last 10 years. She is from a very poor family, and she lost her childhood and didn’t get an education due to their low income. Unfortunately, the person with whom she married is also a poor man and earns a very insufficient income. Farha baji is a mother of four children: three sons and one daughter. Her elder son reads in the 2nd standard. 

Farha baji’s husband is a driver by profession and has been driving an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle) for the last 5 years. Farha baji herself is a housewife and prefers to do household work and take care of her family. Farha baji and her husband have a dream to give their children a better future and good education. She is applying for a loan to repair an auto-rickshaw for her husband so that he'll be able to earn more profit and fulfill the dream for their children.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Nazleen baji wants a loan to buy cable wires for her networking business so that she will be able to provide more TV channels to her community. Lubna baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. Fahmida baji wants a loan to buy clothes to resell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To repair an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle)

loans.name: Sonia's Group

texts.en:
Sonia baji is the wife of Mr. K. and lives in a small area named Bund Road of City Lahore, Pakistan. She owns a two-room brick house and has been living in it for the last 8 years. She is the mother of one son. Her son is Ali and he is 5 years old. Sonia baji’s husband works in a hotel as a waiter. Sonia baji herself is a housewife and prefers to do household work and take care of her family. Her husband wants to start his own business, and he decided to buy a donkey cart, which he wants to use for loading purposes. For that she requires a loan.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Siddiqa baji wants a loan to buy more groceries for her grocery shop. Kalsoom baji wants a loan to buy electrical supplies (tube lights, switchboards) for her electric shop. Budhwanti baji wants a loan to buy old and rough wheels/tires of vehicles to resell. Kiran baji wants a loan to buy more perfumes for her perfume shop.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy a donkey cart for loading purposes

loans.name: Vin

texts.en: Vin P., 51, is married and lives with five of her eight children in Kampong Cham, Cambodia. Since 1998, she has worked as a worker, breaking rock. Normally, she makes around US$5 per day, while her husband works growing yams to earn less than one dollar each day. Vin P. and her husband together have contacted Credit to take out a loan of US$500 to rent a yam farm and then harvest the crop. This couple will slice the yams and then dry them in the sunshine. This investment will help increase the family’s income.

loans.use: To rent a yam farm to harvest a crop.

loans.name: Vanna's Group

texts.en:
This is a small loan group with three members who have chosen Mrs. Vanna as their leader. Mrs. Vanna B., 25, makes a living selling food in a primary school. Her goods include candy, biscuits, desserts and cakes. She has been in this business for ten years and earns around $2.50 per day. Vanna is married to Mr. Vanara Soun, who is 33 years old. The couple has one child. Her husband makes a living repairing TVs, radios and cassette players. Business is good, but he lacks materials needed to make repairs. That is why Vanna is seeking a loan of $300 for her husband to purchase electronic materials. The other two members of this group are:

1- Mrs. Malei U., who sells groceries and needs a loan of $300 to buy inventory to sell.

2- Mrs. Da B., who sells beef soup and needs a loan of $300 to purchase ingredients and repair her kitchen.

Each member of this group lives in Chamkar Samrong Commune in Battabang Province. The man in photo is Mrs. Malei's husband because Malei was not available when the photo was taken.

loans.use: To buy more items to sell

loans.name: Chhin

texts.en: Chhin H., 69, is married and resides in the province of Kampong Cham with her husband. She has three children but all of them no longer stay at home, as they are married and have their own jobs to support their own families. Chhin H. is a farmer and makes less than one dollar per day, while her husband works growing yams, typically making US$8 a day. Chhin H. and her husband have applied for a loan from Kiva via Credit, a local partner, for US$1200 to rent a yam farm and then harvest the crop for sale. They will slice the yams and then dry them in the sunshine.

loans.use: To rent a yam farm and harvest the crop for sale.

loans.name: Kim

texts.en: Kim C., 30, is married and resides with four of her six children and husband in the province of Kampong Cham, in Cambodia. Since 2000, she has worked growing many kinds of vegetables and making rice cakes. She makes the rice cakes with sweet rice, coconut, banana and other ingredients, which are then packed with banana leaves and roasted. On average, she makes about US$3 per day, while her husband, Kim Mou, is a builder. He builds houses and earns US$5 per day. Three children are students and one works selling rubber. Kim C. would like to take out a loan of US$800 to purchase fertilizer and seeds to grow more vegetables.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and seeds to grow more vegetables.

loans.name: Uzma's Group

texts.en:
Uzma baji is the wife of Mr. A. and lives in a small area named Bund Road of City Lahore, Pakistan. Uzma baji couldn’t get an education because her parents couldn’t bear the expenses of her education. She got married at the age of 19. Uzma baji’s husband is a driver and drives a rented auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). He has been driving this for the last 5 years. Uzma baji herself is a housewife and prefers to do household work and take care of her husband. She is applying for a loan to buy her own auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle).

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Razia baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. Nazia baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw. Shumaila baji wants a loan to buy fresh flowers to make bouquets for reselling purposes. Abida baji wants a loan to expand her vegetable-selling business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle)

loans.name: Bun

texts.en: Bun C., 36, is married and lives with two children and her husband in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. Since 2005, she has worked planting beans to earn a profit and is able to make around US$7 each day, while her husband, Keo Hoeun, is a worker and makes US$2.50 per day to support the family. Two of their children are students. Mrs. Bun C. would like to take out a loan of US$500 to purchase fertilizer and bean seeds. Her plan for the future is to provide her children at least a high school education, but if they need to continue beyond that she will be happy to support them even though she knows it will be very expensive. She does not want her children to work as farmers as they will earn less and have to use a lot of labor.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and bean seeds.

loans.name: Tit

texts.en: Tit R., 32, is married and lives with three children and her husband in Kampong Cham, Cambodia. Since 2006, she has worked selling groceries to earn a living and is able to make about US$5 per day, while her husband works selling coconuts to earn approximately US$5 as well. Mrs. Tit R. would like to take out a loan of US$500 to diversify her groceR. inventoR..

loans.use: To diversify her grocery inventory.

loans.name: Mohammad Hussin

texts.en:
Mohammad Hussin is a very young man. He left school when his father died last year. Now this boy is the only support of his family, because his mother is an uneducated woman and he has a small brother. He has a tinsmith shop, a business left from their father. He worked before with his father, and after the death of Hussin's father, he is continuing the business.

He wants to enlarge his shop to better support his family. Therefore he has requested an individual loan of 50,000 Afghanis to enlarge his shop and complete his stock to increase his business and expand his family's available income.

He is happy with this loan process and with all parts of his family. He wants to say that without this loan, it would be impossible to help his family better. He would like to thank all lenders and especially those who will will help him get a loan.

loans.use: To enlarge his shop and complete his stock

loans.name: Rani's Group

texts.en:
Rani baji is a daughter of Mr. W. and lives in a small area named Bund Road of City Lahore, Pakistan. She got divorced from her husband after 20 years of marriage. Presently she is living with her family and has an independent life. She is the mother of five sons. Her three sons have a book-binding business. The others are enrolled in a local school in her neighborhood. Rani baji stays at home and prefers to do household work and take care of her sons. She is applying for a loan to buy material (thread, glue) for her sons' binding business.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Kalsoom baji wants a loan to buy a donkey cart for loading. Aneela baji wants a loan to buy more vegetables to resell. Maryam baji wants a loan to repair her auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle).

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy material for her sons' book-binding business

loans.name: Sak's Group

texts.en:
This is a small loan group with three members. Mrs. Sak D., 56, leads the group and makes a living as a farmer, growing fruits and vegetables for sale. She also makes cakes which she sells from her house. She earns around $5 per day. Mrs. Sak is married to Mr. Leang Eung and has five children, two of whom are married. The other three live at home. One of them helps her make cakes and two are in school. Mrs. Sak is applying for a loan to buy more seeds for her farm. The other two members of this group are:

1- Mrs. Somala C., who is a farmer and needs a loan of $200 to grow vegetable to sell.

2- Mrs. Sreymom K., who is a tailor and needs a loan of $200 to buy a new sewing machine.

All three members of the group live in Chamkar Samrong Commune, Battambang Province

loans.use: To buy items for three small businesses

loans.name: Tasleem's Group

texts.en:
Tasleem baji is the wife of A. M. and lives in a small area named Bund Road, of City Lahore, Pakistan. She owes a brick room and has been living in it for the last 21 years. She is the mother of three sons. Her elder son works in a private bank. The next to him works in a factory. Her younger son is free and doesn’t do anything. Tasleem baji’s husband is a government servant. Tasleem baji herself has a clothing selling business. She has been in this business for the last 10 years. She is applying for a loan to buy more clothes to expand her business.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Razia baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Safia baji wants a loan to buy more cigarettes for her cigarette shop. Suraiya baji wants a loan to buy a buttonhole machine for making shirts.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to resell

loans.name: Nordin

texts.en:
Nordin is an old man with lots of experience, though he is uneducated. He works in agriculture and has been involved in this business for more than 30 years, working with his family during this time. He has some land, but he would love to have more. To buy more land, he needs extra money. Therefore, he requested an individual loan of 50000 Afghani to buy new land and start growing.

He is a professional man and, from when he started his business, he always wanted to improve his business. In the town where he lives, when any of the agricultural men face any difficulties, they come and ask Nordin to help with their problems.

He is grateful for this loan process. He wants to say that it is his first loan and it is really great, especially for agriculture workers. He wants to continue his partnership and encourage other workers to use this loan service.

loans.use: To buy new land and start growing

loans.name: Rehana's Group

texts.en:
Rehana baji is the wife of S. and lives in a small area named Bund Road of City Lahore, Pakistan. She owes a two-room brick house and has been living in it for the last 16 years. She is the mother of six children: five daughters and one son. All of her daughters are married. Her son makes belts and sells them in a market. Rehana baji’s husband works in a factory. Rehana baji herself has a clothes-selling business. She buys clothes from a city named Faisal Abad. Faisal Abad city is famous for its clothes. She has been selling clothes for the last 5 years. She is applying for a loan to buy more clothes to resell.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Rubina baji wants a loan to buy seasonal vegetables to resell. Naseem baji wants a loan to buy a sewing machine to sew clothes. Nusrat baji wants a loan to buy more garments to resell. Nasreen baji wants a loan to expand her paint-selling business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to resell

loans.name: Anna

texts.en: Anna A. is a 22-year-old married mother of three. She lives with her family in Nyalenda slums in Kisumu, Kenya. She is the proprietor of a vegetable stall in the outskirts of Kisumu. She has suplemented her vegetable sales with cereals sales to help maximize her profits. Her hard work, perseverance, good reputation and many years in business coupled with a well-established clientele base ensure that her business will continue to grow despite stiff competition. Anna has applied for a loan of 500 USD, with which she plans to purchase additional stock of cereals and vegetables, saving the remaining amount to use in case of emergencies.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock of vegetables and cereals

loans.name: Thida's Group

texts.en:
This is a small loan group with three members led by Mrs. Thida S.. She is 39 years old and makes a living selling fish which she buys at Tonlesap Lake. She earns about $5 per day. She has a motorcycle which she uses for her business. The family lives in Prek Khpous Commune, Battambang Province. Mrs. Thida has seven children, all of whom live home; one is employed by a private company. Mrs. Thida would like to grow her business and is applying for a loan of $250 to buy more fish to sell. The other two members of her group are:

1- Len H., who is widowed and breeds pigs for sale. She needs a loan of $250 to buy more pigs to breed.

2- Thoun K. is widowed and makes a living selling a local delicacy known as Khmer cake. She needs a loan of $50 to buy ingredients to make additional cakes to sell.

The group people lives in Prek Khporb Commune, Battambang Province.

loans.use: to buy supplies for three small businesses

loans.name: Wilkister

texts.en: Wilkister A. is a 23-year old entrepreneur who lives in Kisumu Kenya with her husband and two living children. Wilkister is a hard working entrepreneur who runs two fruit and vegetable stalls in a busy street in Kisumu. Her hard work, determination and excellent people skills have led to her success. The income generated from her business is able to cover her household expenses. She plans to use three quarters of her loan of US $500 to purchase more stock of fruits in bulk and she will save a bit of it to use in case of emergencies.

loans.use: Purchase stock of fruits.

loans.name: Kosar's Group

texts.en:
Kosar baji is the wife of G. M. and lives in a small area named Bund Road of City Lahore, Pakistan. She has been living in this area for the last 20 years. She is the mother of four children: three sons and one daughter. Her elder son completed his education in the 10th standard and has a furniture-making business. The next to him completed his education in the 12th standard and is now working in an office. Her younger son is completing his bachelor’s degree. Her daughter reads in the 12th standard. Kosar baji’s husband runs a hotel in his community. He has been in this business for the last 20 years. He is a well-known person in his community and everybody comes to him for buying food. Particularly, he sells a Punjabi dish (Nan and Channay). Kosar baji herself is a housewife and also helps her husband in making dishes. She is applying for a loan to buy more materials (cooking oil, lentils, vegetables, rice and spices) for her husband’s food business.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Rubina baji wants a loan to buy more garments to resell. Sabah baji wants a loan to buy another juicer machine for her juice corner. Naeem baji wants a loan to repair her auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Nazia baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy materials for her food business

loans.name: Mourine

texts.en: Mourine O. is a 23-year-old entrepreneur. She lives in Kisumu, Kenya with her husband and two children. Mourine is the proprietor of a retail shop in Nyalenda, Kisumu, a venture she initiated in 2006. She sells fast-moving commonly used items such as bread, milk, sugar, flour, cooking oil, kerosene and soap. Her daily income has increased steadily from the initial 20% to 60%. She plans to expand her business with a bit of her savings and her next loan, which would include selling other items frequently asked by her customers. This would help her maximize profit. She has applied for 500 USD to help her obtain more supplies in bulk.

loans.use: To obtain more supplies

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en:
Veronica A. is a 30-year old entrepreneur. She lives in Kisumu, Kenya with her husband and four children.

Veronica runs a food kiosk where she prepares and sells local foodstuffs. She specializes in making the local favorites, chapattis (fried flat bread) and mandazzis (fried sweet dough), normally served with bean stew and tea. She started this business in 2007.The location of her business and her reputation for doing good business within the community has gained her a wide customer base.

Previous KMET loans were instrumental to the success of her business; she combined the loan money with hard work and perseverance in order to increase her stock and build a successful, income-generating business. She has applied for US $500 to further expand her business.

loans.use: To expand her business.

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en:
This is Ahmad S., who is 51 years old. He is married and has nine children. The family has lived for a long time in Shewa district of the Ningarhar province, which is an agricultural area. Five of his children are studying in a public school, and besides their schooling, they help their father with farming part-time.

Ahmad is an educated man and he is a teacher in the public school of Shewa. He has decided to buy some animals for breeding because he has grassland where he lives in the village. Ahmad also hopes to sell milk and yoghurt. With this plan in mind, he has applied for a 50000AF (US$1050) individual loan for 24 months.

Ahmad hopes that he is able to expand his business so that he can buy more stock to start a stock selling business in future. He thanks the lenders of Kiva.

loans.use: To buy animals

loans.name: Monica

texts.en: Monica O. is a 34-year-old mother of four school-aged children. She is the proprietor of a salon located in Nyalenda, Kisumu, Kenya. She started her salon in 1997 from her small savings. Her salon has done quite well due to the added advantage of access to KMET loan funds; she has combined the additional money with hard work, reputation, excellent skills and perseverance in order to build a successful income-generating activity. She has applied for 500 USD to purchase salon consumables.

loans.use: Purchase saloon consumables

loans.name: Judith

texts.en: Judith A. (standing) is a 35-year-old married mother of five living children. She is the proprietor of a salon in Kisumu Kenya initiated in 2005. The salon is located in a busy street in Nyalenda slums of Kisumu. She has requested US$500 to refurbish her salon which is in bad shape, and also to purchase additional stock of beauty cosmetics.

loans.use: To renovate the salon.

loans.name: Waza's Group

texts.en:
Waza has been selling dresses and lotions in Zanzibar since 2005. She works every day from 8 a.m. to 6 p.m. and earns a profit of approximately 70 USD each month. She is looking forward to taking out her first loan through BRAC Tanzania in order to buy more inventory and increase her profit.

Waza is 23 years old, single, and has one 5-year-old chlid. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Subeha.

loans.use: To buy more dresses and lotions to sell

loans.name: An

texts.en: Mr. An S. H., born in 1983, lives in Preak Thom Village where he is a driver for a company. Since his workplace is far from home, he is requesting a loan to add to his savings to buy a motorbike for commuting to work. His wife, Mrs. Long Sam On, presented on the right in the photo, is employed in a garment factory.

loans.use: To add to his savings to buy a motorbike for commuting to work.

loans.name: Asia's Group

texts.en:
Asia has been preparing and selling food in Zanzibar for ten years. She has previously taken out one loan through BRAC Tanzania, which she repaid successfully and on time. With the help of her last loan, Asia's business expanded such that she is now able to earn a monthly profit of approximately $45. She is hoping that this second, larger loan will enable her to sell a greater quantity of food and further increase her profit.

Asia is 39 years old, married, and has five children, aged 9, 15, 16, 17, and 18. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Khadija, who also owns a small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more ingredients to prepare and sell food.

loans.name: Chea

texts.en: Mrs. Chea S., a 35-year-old widow without any children, lives in Peam Ta Ek Village in Kandal Province where, as  a garment factory worker, she must spend a great deal of money on transportation. In order to reduce her expenses, she is requesting a loan to add to her savings to buy a motorbike for commuting to work.

loans.use: To add the loan to her savings to buy a motorbike for commuting to work.

loans.name: Muazamo

texts.ru: Тураева Муазамо  жительница района Шахринау.Возраст 20 лет, замужем.Образование среднее.Клиентка занимается куплей продажей овощей.Она торгует на рынке района Шахринау.Иммет опыт в бизнесе более 3 лет. Бизнес является основным источником дохода ее семьи. Так как муж клиентки временно не работает. На полученный кредит Муазамо хочет закупить товар.Планирует погасить кредит в течении  12 месяцев
texts.en:
Muazamo T. lives in the Shahrinau region of Tajikistan. She is 20 years old, has a high school degree and is married. Muasamo makes her living selling vegetables at the regional market. She has three years of experience in this business and it is the main source of income for her family, since her husband is temporarily out of work. Muazamo is planning to use this loan to finance the purchase of a large batch of produce. She is wants to pay back this loan in the next 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Anya Lyuksyutova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of goods

loans.name: Tuon

texts.en: Mrs. Tuon A. lives in Boeng Village in Kandal Province. She is a tailor. Her husband, Mr. Siv Ean, is a farmer. Although Mrs. Tuon A. and her husband have different businesses, they still live in poor conditions. In order to improve their standard of living, Mrs. Tuon A. decided to ask for a loan to buy two cows for breeding. She hopes to increase her income after she sells her cows. Mrs. Tuon A. is 50 years old and the mother of four children one of whom is employed in a garment factory while the remaining three are attending the local school. Her husband is shown on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To buy two cows

loans.name: Ruzuwa's Group

texts.en:
Ruzuwa has been preparing and selling food in Zanzibar for three years. She is currently able to earn a profit of approximately 35 USD each month. Ruzuwa is looking forward to receiving her first loan through BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more ingredients, expand her output, and increase her profit.

Ruzuwa is 32 years old, married, and has four children. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Miaema, who also owns a small shop in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more ingredients for preparing and selling food

loans.name: Va

texts.en:
Mrs. Va L. was born in 1942 and she now lives in Svay Village in Kandal Province, Cambodia. She owns a small plot of land where she cultivates rice. 

She now faces a small problem because her field is infertile. To solve this problem, Mrs. Va L. is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer to support her field and make her crop more productive. H

Her husband, Mr. San Sem, gathers palm leaves to process into palm sugar or wine. Mrs. Va L. has two children who are employed in a garment factory.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers

loans.name: Munaza's Group

texts.en:
Munaza baji is the wife of L. A. and lives in a small area named Bund Road of City Lahore, Pakistan. She couldn’t get an education because her parents couldn’t bear the expenses. She owes a two-room brick house and has been living in it for the last 25 years. She is the mother of three children: two sons and one daughter. Her elder son completed his education until the 8th standard and is now working in a factory. Her younger son reads in the 4th standard. Her daughter reads in the 2nd standard. Munaza baji’s husband is a driver by profession and drives an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). He has been driving this for the last 25 years. Munaza baji herself is a housewife and prefers to do household work and take care of her family. She is applying for a loan to repair the auto-rickshaw for her husband so that he able to earn more profit. She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Shagufta baji and Farzana bjai each want a loan to repair their auto-rickshaw. Razia baji wants a loan to repair her pickup vehicle which she uses for loading vegetables and fruits. Humaira baji wants a loan to buy more CD’s for her CD shop.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To repair an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle)

loans.name: Nguon

texts.en:
Mrs. Nguon R. is a villager in Angk Chey Village in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia. She is a farmer who cultivates both rice and potatoes. 

She now faces a small problem because she does not have enough money to hire laborer to work on her field. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan for this purpose. She willl use the rest of the loan to purchase fertilizers and pesticides to make her crop more productive. 

Her husband, Mr. Keom Von, is a motorbike taxi driver who makes a small income to support his family. 

Mrs. Nguon R. is 47 years old and the mother of five children, two of whom help their mother farm while the others attend the local school. Her husband is on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To hire laborer to work on her field, and to purchase fertilizer and pesticides.

loans.name: Thinh

texts.en:
Mr. Thinh S. is a vegetable farmer in Angk Chey Village in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia. 

He now faces a small problem because he does not have enough money to hire laborers to work on his field. Thus, he decided to ask for a loan for this purpose. He will use the rest of the loan to buy more pesticides and fertilizers to make his crop more productive. 

His wife, Mrs. Dul Sokon, helps him on the plantation. Mr. Thinh S. is 50 years old and the father of six children, four of whom assist their parents on the plantation while the remaining two attend the local school. 

His wife is on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To hire laborers to work on the field and he would use the rest of the loan to buy more pesticides and fertilizers to make his crop more productive.

loans.name: Mohira

texts.en: Mohira J. is the mother of three adorable kids. She is a businesslike woman and understands that it is not easy for her husband to feed the family, so she decided to help him by selling men's and women’s clothes at the market. In this way she helps her husband support their family. But she doesn’t have enough money for turnover, so she wants to borrow money in order to buy more goods for sale.

loans.use: Purchasing more clothing for greater sales.

loans.name: Salama's Group

texts.en:
Salama has been selling charcoal in Zanzibar for three years. Charcoal is the primary fuel used for cooking food in Tanzania, as most people do not own an oven or stove. Food items from rice to cakes to octopus are cooked over charcoal. Salama is currently able to earn approximately 10 USD each month selling this fuel. She is looking forward to receiving her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can increase her inventory and sell a greater quantity of charcoal. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her profit.

Salama is 44 years old, married, and has one 23-year-old child. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Time, who also owns a small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To purchase more charcoal for resale

loans.name: Taing

texts.en: Mr. Taing V. is a farmer in Kour Khmuoch Cheing Village in Kampong Cham Province. He usually rents a piece of land to cultivate potatoes. Thus, he decided to ask for a loan to rent a plot of land to grow potatoes. His wife, Mrs. Nan Soeng, helps him in the plantation. Mr. Taing V. is 41 years old and the father of two children who attend the local school. His wife is on the right of the photo.

loans.use: To rent land

loans.name: Nosir

texts.ru: Тураев Носир житель района Шахринау.Возраст 42 года,женат ,имеет 4 детей.Образование среднее.Клиент более 20 лет занимается куплей продажей овощей и фруктов. На доход от торговли он содержит свою большую семью. В данный момент Носир хочет закупить у оптовых поставщиков больше товара.Планирует погасить  кредит в течении 12 месяцев
texts.en:
Nosir T. lives in the Shahrinaw District. He is 42 years old, married, and has four children. He has a secondary education. For over 20 years Nosir has sold fruits and vegetables. The income from sales supports his large family. Now Nosir would like to buy more goods from wholesale providers. He will repay the loan over 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of goods

loans.name: Sein

texts.en: Mrs. Sein K. was born in 1976 and she now lives in Lo Ngeang Village in Kampong Cham Province. She is a vegetable farmer who grows potatoes. She does not have enough money to hire laborers to work in her field. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan for this purpose. Her husband, Mr. Kao Moeun, is a driver who makes a small income to support his family. They have two children, both of whom attend the local school. Her husband is on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To hire laborers

loans.name: Rabia's Group

texts.en:
Rabia baji is the wife of M. A. and lives in a small area named Bund road of City Lahore, Pakistan. She has been living in this area for the last 22 years. She completed her education until the 10th standard. She is the mother of three children: one son and two daughters. None of her children goes to school. Rabia baji’s husband is a shoemaker and sells those pairs in a shoe shop and different markets. He has been in this business for the last 27 years. Rabia baji herself is a housewife but she also sews clothes for her neighbors and earns a profit. She is applying for a loan to buy material (leather, glue, and shoelaces) for her husband so that he able to make more pairs of shoes and increase the profit.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Sania baji wants a loan to buy material (colored thread, clothes and pattenrs) for her decorative embroidery business. Khalida baji wants a loan to buy more clothes to resell. Irshad baji wants a loan to repair her "pick-up” which she uses for loading vegetables and fruits.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy material to make pair of shoes

loans.name: Halima's Group

texts.en:
Halima has been selling soup and bread in Zanzibar since 2005. Soup is usally eaten over rice and is often made up of a tomato- or coconut-based broth and can have bits of meat in it. Halima prepares and sells the food from 7:00am to 6:00pm every day and earns a profit of approximately US$ 35 each month. She is looking forward to receiving her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she may purchase a greater quantity of ingredients so that she can produce more food to sell and increase her profit.

Halima is 26 years old, married, and has 4-year-old twins. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Rahika, who also owns a small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more ingredients to make soup and bread for her small food business.

loans.name: Buk

texts.en: Mrs. Buk K. lives in Lo Ngeang Village in Kampong Cham Province. She has a plot of land where she cultivates rice to earn for living. However, her field is not very fertile. so she decided to ask for a loan to purchase fertilizer to make her crop more productive. Her husband, Mr. Ches Salonh, helps his wife on the plantation. Mrs. Buk K. is 24 years old and the mother of two children, ages one and four. Her husband is on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer

loans.name: Soam

texts.en:
Soam P. is 43 and lives in Siem Reap province with her husband and five children aged 21, 19, 16, 10, and 6. She sells souvenirs near one of the Phimean Akas temples in Angkor Wat which is one of the most visited and holiest areas in Cambodia. She makes about $10 per day. Her husband is 43, and is a cook making about $2 per day. Three of her children are in school, and two work selling books and postcards to the tourists around Angkor Wat, making about $6 per day. Their monthly expenses are about $120.

In the future, Soam P. would like to expand her business further by opening another souvenir shop.

Soam P. is requesting his loan through Kiva’s field partner CREDIT – Micro Finance Institution. CREDIT-MFI has a repayment rate of 99.8% with a portfolio at risk 30+ at 0.33% (taken from their 2007 Annual report). CREDIT – MFI structures their non-agriculture Kiva loans with a declining balance interest rate.  Agriculture loans are structured as balloon repayments with monthly interest rate payments and principle repayments at the end of the loan.

loans.use: To expand the inventory of her souvenir shop.

loans.name: Razia's Group

texts.en:
Razia baji is the wife of M. and lives in an area named Bund Road of City Lahore, Paksitan. She owes a two- room brick house and has been living in it for the last 22 years. She is the mother of three daughters. Her elder daughter is in the 7th standard. The next to her is in the 2nd standard. Her younger daughter is in kindergarten. Razia baji’s husband sells horse food and makes horse carts on order and earns a profit. He has been in this profession for the last 30 years. Razia baji herself is a housewife and prefers to do household work and take care of her family. She is applying for a loan to buy horse food to resell.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Samina baji wants a loan to buy medicines for her clinic. Parveen baji and Kosar baji and Zahida baji each want a loan to buy more clothes to resell. Faiza baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy horse food to resell

loans.name: Chorn

texts.en: Mrs. Chorn M. was born in 1986 and lives in Traov Phny Village in Kampong Cham Province. She owns small piece of land where she grows rice. However, she does not have enough money to buy rice seeds. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan for this purpose. Her husband, Mr. Oeurn Sith, helps on plantation. They have one child who is five years old. Her husband is on the right in the photo.

loans.use: To buy rice seeds

loans.name: Ouk

texts.en:
Ouk H., 45, is a farmer and lives about 124 miles from the capital city of Phnom Penh in Cambodia. Living in the province of Kampong Cham, she typically makes less than US$1 each day. She said planting rice is difficult as the weather conditions are bad. She uses a lot of labor, but can't earn enough to support her family members, and sometimes faces problems with the water supply. She told a loan officer that it so strange that in the rainy season sometimes there is not enough water for the plantation.

Inflation is the main factor that contributes to less profit for every single farmer. The price of everything has skyrocketed, including agricultural products such as fertilizer and rice seed. Most of the farmers cannot afford the high price of fertilizer, and this is why their production is less.

Her husband is a motor-taxi driver and makes US$3. This couple together has three children: one is a garment worker; one is a blacksmith; and the other one works at Siem Reap. Ouk H. is asking for a loan of US$1200 to purchase more blacksmith tools for one of her children to expand his business.

loans.use: To purchase more blacksmith tools.

loans.name: Vuy

texts.en: Mrs. Vuy P. lives in Traov Phny Village in Kampong Cham Province. She is a farmer but she she does not have enough money to buy the rice seed she needs. Therefore, she is requesting a loan to buy rice seeds. Her husband, Mr. Vai Voeurn, sells ice cream in the local village. Mrs. Vuy P. is 38 years old and the mother of three children two of whom attend the local school and the youngest one stays home because he is too young for school. Her husband is on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To buy rice seeds

loans.name: Fani's Group

texts.en:
Fani has a small business in Zanzibar. She is 25 years old and married. She is now hoping to take out her first loan through BRAC Tanzania in order to buy more inventory for her shop and increase her profit.

She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Zabibu, who also owns a small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To expand her business.

loans.name: Tuot

texts.en: Mrs. Tuot S. is a 32-year-old widow with a 4-year-old child. She is a villager in Chineang  Village in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia. She is a famer and she now faces a problem because she does not have enough money to cultivate her crops. Therefore, she is requesting a loan to buy fertilizer and rice seeds to plant.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and rice seeds to plant.

loans.name: Naoe

texts.en: Mrs. Naoe S. is a villager in Chineang in Kampong Cham Province. She and her husband, Mr. Yang Yaing, own a piece of land where they cultivate rice to earn for living. Additionally, they are breeders who raise two cows, three buffaloes, and three pigs. In their plantation, they now have a problem because they do not have enough money to buy rice seeds. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan for this purpose. She will use part of the money to purchase fertilizer to make her crop more productive. Mrs. Naoe S., 33, is married without any children. Her husband is on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To buy rice seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Hajra

texts.en:
Hajra has owned a small shop in Zanzibar for seven years. She works from 7 a.m. to 6 p.m. every day and is able to earn a profit of approximately $150 each month. She is now hoping that this loan from BRAC Tanzania will enable her to expand her inventory and increase her profit.

Hajra is 26 years old, married, and has a 3-year-old child.

loans.use: To buy more inventory for her shop.

loans.name: Thoeun

texts.en: Thoeun P., 30, is married and lives about 124 miles from the capital city of Phnom Penh in Cambodia. Living in the province of Kampong Cham, she typically makes about US$1 each day, raising pigs. Her husband has a business of transporting sand and soil by truck to build roads. On average, he makes US$10 each day. This couple has three children, two of whom are students. Thoeun P. would like to take out a loan of US$1000 to breed more pigs.

loans.use: To breed more pigs.

loans.name: Sin

texts.en:
Mrs. Sin M. is a villager in Tany village in Kampong Cham Province. She is a duck breeder. Since her duck flock is getting bigger and bigger, she does not have enough money to buy food so she is requesting a loan to purchase more food to feed her ducks. Her husband, Mr. En Om, owns a hectar to cultivate rice to earn a living.

Mrs. Sin M. is 39 years old and the mother of six children one of whom is employed in a garment factory while another is a farmer. Three others are enrolled in the local school while the youngest one is three years old so that child is too young to work or study. Her husband is shown in the photo.

loans.use: To purchase more food to feed her ducks

loans.name: Sam

texts.en:
Sam Ngut is 26 years old and lives in Siem Reap Province with her husband and two twin children, both of whom who are four years old. She sells souvenirs near the Phimean Akas temple near Angor Wat, one of the most visited and holiest areas in Cambodia. She makes about $5 per day. Her husband is 24 years old and sells paintings near the Phimean Akas temple as well, and also earns about $5 per day. On average their monthly expenses are about $180.

Sam Ngut is requesting his loan through Kiva’s field partner CREDIT – Micro Finance Institution. CREDIT-MFI has a repayment rate of 99.8% with a portfolio at risk 30+ at 0.33% (taken from their 2007 Annual report). CREDIT – MFI structures their non-agriculture Kiva loans with a declining balance interest rate. Agriculture loans are structured as balloon repayments with monthly interest rate payments and principle repayments at the end of the loan. To learn more about CREDIT-MFI please visit their Kiva Field Partner page or their website at

http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=9

http://www.credit.com.kh/

loans.use: Sam Ngut is requesting a loan of $600 to increase her inventory at her souvenir shop and provide more paintings for her husband’s shop. Their shops are near Angkor Wat which is a tourist attraction with an increasing number of visitors each year.

loans.name: Muhammad

texts.en:
Muhammad H., 44, is married with six children. They live with his parents in Shewa Nangarhar province, Jalalabad city. He is a teacher in his village school and also he works in animal husbandry because he has grassland.

H. has three sons and three daughters. It is important to him to educate his children. H. has a plan to make a canteen (school shop) in the school. For that he needs 50,000AF (US$ 1,050) as an individual loan for 24 months.

Therefore he got in contact with the lenders of AFSG to give him 50,000AF in an individual loan. With this money he wants to buy various things such as notebooks, pens, pencils, and sharpeners or other things for the canteen. He has his own capital of 32,000AF (US$ 654) to add to the loan and he can solve his problem. He says, "Thanks Kiva; thanks a lot to the lenders!"

loans.use: buying notebooks, pens, pencils, etc.

loans.name: Mwanakheri's Group

texts.en:
Mwanakheri S. has been selling shoes in Zanzibar since 2007. She works every day from 8 a.m. to 6 p.m. and is able to earn a profit of approximately $45 each month. With her first loan from BRAC Tanzania, Mwanakheri intends to purchase more inventory for her shop so that she can increase her profit.

Mwanakheri is 42 years old, married, and has five children, ages 1, 5, 9, 12 and 13. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Halima, who also has a small shop in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more shoes as inventory for her shop.

loans.name: Pok

texts.en: Mrs. Pok S. lives in Siem Reap province, Cambodia. She and her husband, 65 years old, together work making various kinds of baskets from bamboo and resell them to a broker who comes to collect at their base. Pok S. has two children. One of them sells baskets at a distant market near a Thai border and another works as a mechanic. To meet her customer demands and increase her profit margin, Pok S. would like a loan to purchase more bamboo and other materials.

loans.use: To buy more bamboo and other materials to produce more baskets.

loans.name: Lim

texts.en: Lim K., 47, lives with her husband and six children in the Kampong Cham, Cambodia. Since 1990, she has worked in her rice field to earn a living but she makes less than $1 USD each day. She told a loan officer that farmers make very little profit. Her husband is a construction worker who builds house and makes $3 USD per day. Three children are employed and one is a student. Lim K. would like to take out a loan of $600 USD to purchase a motorbike for her husband's commute to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Yein

texts.en: Yein S. is 37 years old and is a rice farmer who resides with two young children and her husband in Kampong Cham, Cambodia. She typically makes about $3 each day, while her husband works selling coconuts in the village. He owns a motorbike and trailer and transports the coconuts to the village. On average, he makes $10 per day. Yein S. would like to take out a loan of $400 to replace an old motorbike for her husband. The old motorbike uses a lot of gas, and often needs repair, costing a lot of money to maintain.

loans.use: To replace an old motorbike.

loans.name: Pheng

texts.en: Pheng P. is 45 and is married with four children. She lives in the Siem Reap province, Cambodia. She is a pig breeder and has started her lives stock since 1995. Her husband is self-employed as a motor-taxi driver and typically makes about $5/day for his household. She and her husband would really like to buy another motor-bike so one of their children can earn money as a motor-taxi driver as well. They believe a new motor-bike will generate more profit for their household. (Her husband is pictured with this motor-bike, while Pheng P. is not available).

loans.use: To buy a motor-bike  to operate a business.

loans.name: Bea

texts.en: Bea H., 31, is married and lives with three young children and her husband in the Kampong Cham, Cambodia. She works together with her husband as a farmer. She grows rice at the field and her husband plants vegetables at home. This couple earns a combined amount of around US$3 each day. Bea H. is asking a loan of US$200 to breed pigs for extra profit to raise their standard of living.

loans.use: To raise pigs.

loans.name: Chhean

texts.en:
Ms. Chhean S. N. is 26 years old and is married with two children. She stays at home and takes care of the family, while her husband, Mr. Men Sokhom, works as a chef at Monor Reach Hotel in Siem Riep Province. Her children are aged four and six, and both attend school. On average, the family income is about $5 per day.

Chhean S. N. is requesting a loan of $400 to purchase a motor-bike for her husband to commute to work. Currently, he pays for a moto-taxi every day, which is just too expensive. Moto-taxi fares have gone up over the past year to reflect rising gas prices and inflation. In the future, Chhean S. N. would like to own a grocery store. This would help generate more income for her household.

(Chhean S. N. was not available for the picture. The picture is of her husband and their two children.)

Chhean S. N. is requesting a loan through Kiva’s field partner CREDIT – Micro Finance Institution. CREDIT-MFI has a repayment rate of 99.8% with a portfolio at risk 30+ at 0.33% (taken from their 2007 Annual report). CREDIT – MFI structures their non-agriculture Kiva loans with a declining balance interest rate. Agriculture loans are structured as balloon repayments with monthly interest rate payments and principle repayments at the end of the loan. To learn more about CREDIT-MFI please visit their Kiva Field Partner page or their website at

http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=9

http://www.credit.com.kh/

loans.use: To purchase a motor-bike for her husband to commute to work

loans.name: Phim

texts.en: Phim R. is fifty-three years old. She sells grocery products, including food, to people in her area, making about $4 to $5 a day. Since her husband passed away many years ago, Phim R. has been working very hard to provide her children with a better quality of life. Phim R. started her grocery business in 2000 and hopes to expand more as her business continues to do well. She has applied for a loan from a Kiva field’s partner CREDIT MFI to purchase more grocery products for her business expansion.

loans.use: To buy more grocery products to mee ther client demands.

loans.name: Nov

texts.en: Nov T. is a 60 year old widow who resides with her two children in Kampong Cham, Cambodia. She sells rice and makes $4 per day. She is aided by her two children who work selling rice noodles. Mrs. Nov is asking for a loan of $500 to increase her rice inventories.

loans.use: To add rice stock.

loans.name: Mwanakhamis

texts.en:
Mwanakhamis A. has been selling fabric and clothing in Zanzibar since 2005. She works daily from 8 a.m. to 6 p.m. and is able to earn a profit of approximately $45 each month. She is looking forward to taking out her first loan through BRAC Tanzania so that she can expand her inventory and increase her profit.

Mwanakhamis is married and has three children, ages 1, 3 and 7.

loans.use: To buy more clothing to stock her small shop.

loans.name: Chea

texts.en: Chea S., 48, is a rice farmer who lives with four children in the Kampong Cham, Cambodia. Since 1990, she has been growing rice to earn a living and is able to make less than one dollar per day. Normally, her farm provides just enough for the family and she does not usually sell rice for extra profit as annual output is low. Farmers almost totally depend on the sky to farm, as in most of the provinces, there are no irrigation systems yet. Currently, the weather conditions are getting better, but still in some places there is only light rain. Her husband, Mao Hun, 25, works planting vegetables at home and sells at the market to earn approximately US$3 in profits per day. Besides farming, they also raise pigs. Chea S. would like to take out a loan of US$300 to purchase feed for their pigs.

loans.use: To purchase feed for pigs.

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
Sok P. is 47 years old, and lives in the Siem Reap Province with her husband and their 5 children. Sok P. takes care of the house and works as a farmer, while her husband drives a motor-taxi, earning on average about $6 per day. Three of her children go to school, and one works as a housekeeper at a hotel and makes about $2 per day.

Sok P. is requesting a loan through Kiva’s field partner CREDIT – Micro Finance Institution. CREDIT-MFI has a repayment rate of 99.8% with a portfolio at risk of 30+ at 0.33% (taken from their 2007 Annual report). CREDIT – MFI structures their non-agriculture Kiva loans with a declining balance interest rate. Agriculture loans are structured as balloon repayments with monthly interest rate payments and principle repayments at the end of the loan. To learn more about CREDIT-MFI please visit their Kiva Field Partner page or their website at

http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=9

http://www.credit.com.kh/

loans.use: Purchasing a motorbike for commuting

loans.name: Sim

texts.en:
Sim R., 39, is married with three children and works selling sugar cane juice around her town. She has a motor-bike attached to a cart that enables to travel around to sell her products. With her business activity, she can generate $5 per day of profit. 
Her husband is a farmer growing crops and vegetables. He can make around $2.50 per day by selling his crops to the people at a market.
Recently, she has asked for a loan from KIVA to buy a new motor-bike and buy more sugar cane to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more sugar cane to expand her business

loans.name: Sat

texts.en: Sat S., 23, is married and lives with two young children and her husband in the Kampong Cham, Cambodia. She has a business selling bananas, earning a profit of $5 each day. Actually, she rents the banana farm from the villagers and then carries the fruit to sell at the market. Her husband, Phoeun Thon, 27, is a horse-cart driver. On average, he makes $3 per day to support the family as well. Mrs. Sat S. would like to take out a loan of $800 to rent a banana farm. With this loan, she would be able to carry more fruit than ever before to sell to the market.

loans.use: To rent banana farm.

loans.name: Mut

texts.en: Mut A. is 27 years old, widowed and makes a living growing rice and vegetables in Phteah Rung Commune in Pursat Province. She has been a farmer for ten years and currently earns around $2 per day. Mut cares for her two children, both of whom are in school. Mut is a good mother and works hard every day to generate income and take care of her young family. She needs a loan of 50,000 ($125) to buy seeds, which she will use to grow more vegetable to sell. She hopes the loan will allow her to increase her family’s income.

loans.use: to buy seeds for her farm

loans.name: Ashura

texts.en:
Ashura prepares and sells food in Zanzibar. Every day, she cooks from 7:00am to 8:00pm and sells enough food so that she is able to earn a profit of approximately $120 each month. She is hoping to use her first loan from BRAC Tanzania to buy more ingredients so that she may cook and sell a greater quantity of food.

Ashura is 29 years old, married and has 3 children, aged 3, 5 and 8.

loans.use: To increase her inventory to produce and sell food.

loans.name: Pov

texts.en: Pov N., 74, is a farmer who lives with his four children in Kampong Cham, Cambodia. He grows and sells rice and cucumbers from his home. He makes around $1 per day and is aided by one of his children who works in the garment factory. The rest of the children stay at home and help him with the farming. Besides farming he also raises fish for extra profit. Pov N. would like to take out a loan of $1000 to purchase fertilizers and a water pump to increase the efficiency of his farm.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and a water pump.

loans.name: Valentina

texts.en:
Valentina is a happy mom who has raised two kids. They are now grown and live separately. Moreover, she is a successful entrepreneur from Kahovka in the Kherson region in southeastern Ukraine. Valentina sells footwear in one of the local markets. She’s been in the trade for 12 years. The economic crisis and high unemployment rates forced her to launch a small venture and take the financial risks that come along with it. Valentina managed not only to survive in highly unfavorable surroundings but also made her business sustainable. Currently, she has about $6,000 in stock. Her monthly net profit is a little over $400. 
	
Valentina says she is happy to be able to provide for her family and realizes they have everything they need for a normal life. Moreover, she enjoys working with people on a daily basis, learning to serve her customers better and getting more experience along the way. This time Valentina is requesting a 5,000 Grivna loan to re-stock her inventory for the fall/winter season. She is hoping to repay the current loan in 10 months.

loans.use: increase income

loans.name: In

texts.en:
In S. is 48 years old and lives in Siem Reap Province  with her husband and 5 children. She sells roast beef and roast frog, traveling door-to-door, earning on average US$ 7 per day. Her husband, Ros Yun is 49 years old and is a fisherman earning about US$ 6 per day. 

Her youngest child goes to school while the other 4 work. They all work in different industries. One works with his father, another as a construction worker; one sells cloth, and the fourth works as a gardener at a golf course.  Their household expenses are about US$ 85 per month.

In S. was not available for the picture. Her husband is pictured with his boat. In future In S. would like to have a stand at the market. This loan will be used to expand her husband's business.

In S. is requesting a loan through Kiva’s field partner CREDIT – Micro Finance Institution. CREDIT-MFI has a repayment rate of 99.8% with a portfolio at risk 30+ at 0.33% (taken from their 2007 Annual report). CREDIT – MFI structures their non-agriculture Kiva loans with a declining balance interest rate.  Agricultural loans are structured as balloon repayments with monthly interest rate payments and principle repayments at the end of the loan. To learn more about CREDIT-MFI, please visit their Kiva Field Partner page or their website at 

http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=9

http://www.credit.com.kh/

loans.use: to purchase a boat and fishing nets for her husband’s fishery business

loans.name: Valentina

texts.en:
Valentina is a bright example of a self-made entrepreneur. She started her small venture 10 years ago in hard times during the shaky economic transformation of a developing state. An urgent need to find ways to support her family was the factor that motivated her in business endeavors. Today Valentina has learned a lot in the school of life about competition. She has a stable and growing business selling clothing in one of the local marketplaces in her home town of Kahovka. Presently, she has $4,000 in merchandise. Her net profit is about $440 a month.

Valentina is divorced, her children are grown, and she can devote a lot of energy to her developing enterprise. She always says she enjoys watching her business growing and becoming more and more stable as time goes by. Valentina is seeking a 5,000 Grivna loan for further expansion of her business. We believe this client’s credit history, outstanding performance and significant achievements secure prompt repayment of the current loan as well.

loans.use: increase income

loans.name: Anbenakan (We Are In Agreement) Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe anbenakan est un regroupement de huit femmes de la grande famille élargie des bûcherons du village de Kimparana préfecture de San (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali). Toutes mariées elles ont en moyenne 44 ans et 6 enfants.
Appartenant à une ethnie du Mali qui s’occupe de la confection de calebasses, des ustensiles, la fabrication des cantines et des boites à bijoux en calebasses. Cette activité a été apprise auprès des parents pendant l’enfance. En plus de cette activité, elles font le commerce de condiments alimentaires.
Afin d’augmenter la taille de leurs activités, elles ont décidé ensemble d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis plus de deux ans. Après avoir correctement remboursé les quatre premiers prêts de groupe (prêt solidaire), le groupe est à son cinquième prêt et compte l’utiliser pour acheter, la matière première entrant dans l’exercice de leur activité principale à savoir les cuirs, les ficelles, les gourdes, les calebasses, les feuilles de rôniers etc.
Elles s’approvisionnent auprès des paysans en feuilles de rônier, en calebasses et en gourdes et en cuirs et ficelle auprès des commerçants du marché.
Les travaux sont exécutés à la maison pour fabriquer des calebasses, des cantines et boites à bijoux. Par contre elles se déplacent de familles en familles pour réparer ces dits objets. La clientèle est composée essentiellement de femmes et des fans des objets d’art traditionnels du Mali.
Avec les revenus qu’elles généreront, elles comptent rembourser les intérêts du prêt et faire face aux dépenses de la famille.
texts.en:
The group Anbenakan consists of 8 women from the big extended family of woodcutters of the village of Kimparana, Prefecture of San (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). All are married, have an average age of 44 and on average 6 children.

They belong to an ethnic group which works with gourds, making utensils, trunks, and jewelry boxes from the calabash (bottle gourd). This technique is passed on from parents to their offspring in childhood. Besides this business, these women sell condiments.

So as to expand the size of their businesses, they decided to all join the loan program of Soro Yiriwaso more than 2 years ago.
