After having correctly reimbursed their first four group loans (solidarity loans), this group is ready for their 5th loan and hopes to use it to buy raw materials for their main business, i.e., leather, string, gourds, calabashes and palm fronds.

They buy their palm fronds from peasants and calabashes, gourds, leather, and string from merchants at the market.

The handiwork is done at home to make drinking gourds, trunks, and jewelry boxes. They then go from family to family to gather these objects. Their clientele is composed essentially of women and people who are keen on these traditional Malian handicrafts.

With their earnings, they expect to make payments on the loan and help support their families.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buying raw materials (leather, palm fronds, calabashes etc.)

loans.name: Zorica

texts.en:
Zorica was born in 1971 and lives in Karanovac, a village in Bosnia outside of Petrovo. She is married and the mother of two children, ages 4 and 15 months. She owns two stores with her mother, with each of the owning 50%. One of the stores is located across the street from her house, which allows her to both work and spend time with her kids.

Zorica requests a 1,200KM loan from Women for Women International in order to expand the product offering at her stores. She expects that this will increase her client base.

This loan is guaranteed by her friend, Dragana Dragičević. If Zorica is unable to repay her loan, Dragana will cover the repayments.

Zorica's youngest son is pictured. He usually spends his days at the store with his mom. Zorica also has a small garden where she grows vegetables for her family’s consumption.

loans.use: to purchase additional products for her grocery store

loans.name: Mwanaidi

texts.en:
Mwanaidi has been selling kanga and other fabrics in Zanzibar for five years. "Kanga" is a local fabric that is often brightly colored and can have one of a huge variety of patterns on it. They also contain a local adage written in Swahili at the bottom. Kanga is used for everything from clothing and baby slings to table cloths and sofa covers. Mwanaidi works every day from 8 a.m. to 10 p.m. selling her fabrics and is able to earn a monthly profit of approximately $45.

Mwanaidi is married and has four children, ages 10, 12, 14 and 16.

loans.use: To buy more kanga fabric for her shop.

loans.name: Yoeung

texts.en: Yoeung S., 50, is a widow who lives with one of her three children in the Kampong Cham, Cambodia. She sells fruits and fried bananas to earn a living and is able to make around US$6 each day. She is also supported by her three children who work in a garment factory. She is asking for a loan of US$1000 to diversify and expand her business. She will purchase more fruits and she will buy a bigger pan to fry bananas as well.

loans.use: To sell more fruits.

loans.name: Boeurn

texts.en: Mrs. Boeurn A., 36, is a farmer. She is married and has four children; her eldest one is employed as a worker at a shoe producing firm in Pursat town, and the other three are in school. Her husband, Von Yem, 41, is a construction worker, earning around $4 per day. Boeurn’s farming business is not going well because she lacks oxen to use for plowing farmland. Hence, she would like to request a loan of $500 to purchase two oxen to use for her farming business. (Mrs. Boeurn was not available for taking picture and her husband insteaded)

loans.use: To purchase two oxen to use for her faming business

loans.name: Thai

texts.en:
Thai P., who is 47 years old, is a widow and lives with her parents in the Prey veng province of Cambodia. Thai P. started a livestock raising pigs in 2004. Usually, she buys pig from other breeders and starts raising them.
 After six to seven month her pigs will grow enough such that she can sell them to others in her area. 

Recently, P. has applied a loan from KIVA to purchase more pigs to breed.

loans.use: To buy more pigs to breed

loans.name: Nadhira

texts.en:
Nadhira has owned a small shop in Zanzibar since 2007. She sells miscellaneous household items like detergent and snacks. She works every day from 8 a.m. to 6 p.m. and is able to earn a profit of approximately $65 each month. She will use her first loan from BRAC Tanzania to buy more inventory for her shop to increase her profit.

Nadhira is 44 years old, married, and has five children, ages 9, 12, 14, 18 and 26.

loans.use: To buy more inventory for her shop.

loans.name: Dragana

texts.en:
Dragana Dragičević was born in 1971 and lives in Karanovac, a village in Bosnia outside of Petrovo. She is married with two children, one who is employed and one who is in primary school. Her husband and older son both work together as welders. The family lives together in one house, which is located on a corn field. Dragana grows and sells corn, raises pigs, and maintains a vegetable garden with which she helps to feed her family. She wants to start raising chickens to generate additional income, as a reserve for when the corn harvest does not yield adequate corn.

Dragana requests a loan of 1,200KM from Women for Women International. She will use this loan to purchase chickens and supplies for housing the chickens through the winter. She will feed the chickens with the corn and vegetables she grows in her fields, which is usually the highest expense for raising poultry.

She is a friendly, good-spirited woman, who immediately joked that it would be clear to everyone that she is a farmer, based on the clothes she is wearing in the photograph.

This loan is guaranteed by her friend, Zorica Ristić. If Dragana is unable to repay her loan, Zorica will cover the repayments.

loans.use: To purchase chickens and the materials needed to house the chickens through the winter.

loans.name: Benkadi (Unity Is Good) Group

texts.fr:
Benkadi est un regroupement de sept femmes du  deuxième quartier de la ville de Koutiala (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles ont une moyenne d’âge de 37 ans et  6 enfants. Les femmes du groupe Benkadi vivent dans des familles polygames avec leurs enfants, les coépouses, les beaux parents, les frères et soeurs et d’autres parents.
Ce groupe fait essentiellement le commerce des condiments alimentaires et souvent les pâtes alimentaires, les chaussures et l’habillement.
Se connaissant depuis de longue date et se faisant mutuellement confiance, elles ont décidé ensemble d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis deux ans. Benkadi est à son troisième prêt solidaire(prêt de groupe) après avoir remboursé sans difficulté les deux précédents. Le prêt actuel sera utilusé pour acheter, des cartons de lait, des sacs d’oignons, des cartons de macaroni etc auprès des grossistes en provenance de la république du Ghana, de Dakar (capitale  de la république du Sénégal et d’Abidjan ( capitale de la Côte d’ivoire).
Avec une clientèle à majorité constituée de femmes, les membres de ce groupe effectuent leurs ventes exclusivement au marché de Koutiala très généralement au comptant. Elles comptent réaliser en moyenne 100 000 CFA par cycle et ambitionnent de devenir des grossistes et aller faire des achats dans les pays cités ci dessus..
NB La nommée Mariam Dembélé est absente de la photo de groupe pour des raisons de visites prénatales.
texts.en:
Benkadi is a group of 7 women from the second suburb of the town of Koutiala (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They have an average age of 37 and on average, 6 children. The women of the Benkadi group live in polygamous families with their children, co-spouses, parents-in-law, brothers, sisters, and other relatives.

This group basically sells condiments and often also pasta, shoes, and clothing.

Since they have known each other for a long time and trust one another, they decided to come together to join the loan program of Soro Yiriwaso two years ago. Benkadi is on its third solidarity loan (group loan) after having reimbursed the two preceding ones without difficulty. This third loan will be used to buy cartons of milk, sacks of onions, cartons of macaroni, etc. from the wholesalers--goods which come from the Republic of Ghana, from Dakar (capital of Senegal) and from Abidjan (capital of the Cote d'Ivoire).

Having a clientele mainly consisting of women, the members of this group make their sales exclusively in the market of Koutiala, generally on a cash basis. They expect to make, on average, 100,000 CFA each time they have sold off what they bought and their ambition is to become wholesalers and go to do their own buying in the aforementioned cities.

Note that Mariam Dembélé is absent from the photo because she had a prenatal checkup at that time.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of condiments for re-sale

loans.name: Theng

texts.en: Theng H., aged 47, is a widow who lives with three children in Kampong Cham, Cambodia. Since 2000, she has been selling groceries to the people in the village and makes approximately $4.50 each day. Her income is supplemented by two of her children who work at a construction site. Mrs. Theng H. would like to take out a loan of $700 to add more groceries to her inventory.

loans.use: To add groceries to her inventory.

loans.name: Salama

texts.en:
Salama has owned a small shop in Zanzibar for two years. She sells a variety of goods including perfumes, bed sheets and small food items. She works every day from 7 a.m. to 6 p.m. and is able to earn approximately $65 each month. With her first loan from BRAC Tanzania, Salama hopes to buy more inventory for her shop so that she can increase her profit.

Salama is 31 years old, divorced, and has three children, ages 5, 11 and 15.

loans.use: To buy more inventory for her small shop.

loans.name: Yim

texts.en: Yim O., 43, works as a rice farmer, making $4 per day. Her husband runs a business charging batteries in his community. The battery charging business is doing well as most people use batteries to generate electricity, given that there are no power lines running to the community. Yim O.'s husband makes five dollars on a typical day. The couple has applied for a loan to purchase a charging machine that enables them to recharge batteries faster and more efficiently, what should be a profitable investment. (Mr. O. is pictured).

loans.use: To buy a charging machine that enable her husband to charge many batteries in a time.

loans.name: Mastona

texts.en: Mastona T. has been selling dried apricots for many years. It is very hard work. She goes to a city far away and buys apricots there for a cheaper price. Then she brings the apricots home and dries them, which takes about a week. After that she sells the apricots at the market. Everything is more expensive now, and she wants to borrow money to buy more apricots so that she won’t lose her clients.

loans.use: Buying more apricots for sale

loans.name: Shufaa

texts.en:
Shufaa has been preparing and selling food in Zanzibar for three years. She is currently able to earn approximately $125 each month. She is hoping her first loan from BRAC Tanzania will allow her to buy more ingredients so that she can prepare a greater quantity of food and increase her profit.

Shufaa is 28 years old, single, and has 10-year-old twins.

loans.use: To buy more ingredients to cook and sell.

loans.name: Chuong

texts.en: Chuong T., 26, is married and lives with two young children and her husband in the Kampong Cham, Cambodia. She works together with her husband as construction builders, building houses. They make a combined amount around US$7 each day. Mrs. Chuong would like to take out a loan of US$800 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to run a motor-taxi whenever he is free from construction work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Va

texts.en:
Va S. is 38 years old and is married with two children. She is a housewife, while her husband is the head of the family to support his household. He works as a construction foreman.
Occasionally he has to hire three or four workers to work with him. Before the building is constructed he must sign a contract with the construction owners about the construction timeframe and wages for him and his co-workers.

Recently, Va S. has applied for a loan from KIVA to purchase her husband more construction tools to expedite his work and the leftovers from the loan will be paid to his construction workers.

loans.use: To buy more construction tools .

loans.name: Benkadi (Unity) Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre femmes (trois mariées et une veuve) du groupe benkadi de l’association Kégnéreyè ont en moyenne 45 ans et 3 enfants. Elles vivent dans des foyers traditionnels dans le village de Kimparana de la préfecture de San (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali)
Ce groupe de femmes fait essentiellement le commerce en gros de condiments alimentaires. Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, elles ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis deux ans. Après avoir correctement remboursés les trois prêts précédents, ce groupe est à son quatrième prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe). Pour augmenter leur marge bénéficiaire elles font des achats groupés auprès des grossistes à Bamako (capitale de la république du Mali). Les achats concernent le laye, les oignons, du soumbala (pâte alimentaire fabriquée à partir des noix de néré), les aromes et autres épices. Les femmes du groupe benkadi vendent leurs marchandises à la maison et au marché de kimparana où les détaillants viennent s’y ravitailler à crédit hebdomadairement. Le cycle d’achat et de vente du groupe dure en moyenne une semaine. Par conséquent elles s’approvisionnent chaque semaine.
Elles espèrent réaliser en moyenne et par personne un bénéfice mensuel de 50 000 CFA. qui sera utilisé pour renforcer le fonds de commerce et acheter les trousseaux de mariages pour les filles. Elles ambitionnent d’ouvrir à l’avenir une boutique de stockage et de vente de condiments à Kimparana.
texts.en:
The four women (three married and one widowed) of the Benkadi group of the association Kégnéreyè have an average age of 45 and on average 3 children. They live in traditional households in the village of Kimparana, Prefecture of San (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

This group of women essentially wholesales condiments. To expand the size of their businesses, they decided two years ago to join the loan program of Soro Yiriwaso. After having correctly reimbursed three preceding loans, they are ready for their fourth solidarity loan (group loan). To increase their profit margin, they group their purchases from wholesalers in Bamako (capital of the Republic of Mali). They purchase onions, soumbala (an edible paste made of néré nuts), flavorings and other spices. The women of the Benkadi group sell out of their homes and in the marketplace of Kimparana where retailers come weekly to purchase on credit. The buying and selling cycle of the group lasts on average one week. Therefore, they do their buying once a week.

They each hope to make on average a monthly profit of 50,000 F CFA which they intend to use to bolster their working capital and buy wedding trousseaus for their daughters. They would like in future to open a shop where they could warehouse and sell condiments in Kimparana.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of condiments for re-sale .

loans.name: Riziki

texts.en:
Riziki M. has been selling charcoal and firewood in Zanzibar for 10 years. These are necessities for her neighbors as they are the primary fuel used to prepare food. Few people own ovens or stoves, so food is cooked over a fire. She works from 8 a.m. to 8 p.m. every day and is able to earn a profit of approximately $35 each month. She is hoping that her first loan from BRAC Tanzania will enable her to stock more inventory so that she can increase her profit.

Riziki is 40 years old, married, and has seven children, ages 4, 7, 10, 16, 18, 20 and 24.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and firewood to sell.

loans.name: Meak

texts.en: Meak S., 43, is a widow who lives with her two children in the Kampong Cham, Cambodia. She is a member of the stage performances held in the village and also works selling different kinds of dessert. On average, she makes US$5 each day, but is also supported by two of her children who work in a garment factory and as a mechanic. She would like to take out a loan of US$800 to open a mechanic shop for her son so he can earn more profits to raise their standard of living. In the future, she would like to sell groceries instead of desserts as well.

loans.use: To open a mechanic shop.

loans.name: Benkadi (Unity) Group

texts.fr:
Composé de cinq (5) femmes toutes mariés les membres du groupe Benkadi de l’association Yiriwaton ont en moyenne 39 ans avec 6 enfants. Vivant dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies (avec beaux parents, beaux frères, soeurs, nièces, fils, cousins, petits fils etc.), elles habitent dans le village de Kimparana préfecture de San (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali)
Les membres du groupe, en plus de leur activité principale qu’est l’achat et la vente des noix de néré font également la cueillette et la vente du soja.
Unies par des liens économique et social, elles sont à leur premier prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe) avec Soro Yiriwaso.
Elles comptent utiliser ce prêt pour acheter, des sacs de noix de néré auprès des femmes qui font la cueillette et de quelques commerçants spécialisés dans ce domaine. Les produits ainsi achetés sont revendus au marché de Kimparana à des revendeurs venant des grandes villes (tel Ségou, et Bamako). Ce cycle est renouvelé chaque semaine. L’essentiel des bénéfices servira à faire face aux dépenses familiales (scolarité, santé et nourriture).
NB : Pour des raisons sociales la nommée Tata Traoré est absente de la photo de groupe.
texts.en:
Consisting of 5 married women, the members of the Benkadi group of the association Yiriwaton have an average age of 39 and on average, 6 children. Living in big traditional extended families (with parents-in-law, brothers- and sisters-in-law, nieces, sons, cousins, grandsons, etc.) they are residents of the village of Kimparana, Prefecture of San (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

The members of the group gather and sell soy beans, besides their main business of buying néré tree nuts.

United by economic and social ties, they are on their first solidarity loan (group loan) with Soro Yirwaso. They intend to use this loan to buy sacks of néré tree nuts from other women who gather them and from some merchants specialized in this field. The products they buy will be sold at the market in Kimparana to wholesalers who come from the big cities (such as Ségou and Bamako). This cycle is repeated every week. Most of their profit will be used for family expenditures (school fees, health-related expenses, and food).

Note: for societal reasons, Tata Traoré is absent from the group photo.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of nuts from the néré tree for re-sale

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha has been cooking and selling food in Zanzibar for three years. She is currently able to earn a profit of approximately $45 each month, but she is hoping that her first loan from BRAC Tanzania enables her to increase this profit, as she will be able to purchase ingredients in bulk and produce a greater output of products.

Asha is 27 years old, married, and has two children, aged 4 and 7.

loans.use: To buy more ingredients to cook and sell food.

loans.name: Meak

texts.en: Meak S. is 41 years old, married, and lives with her husband and four children in Kampong Cham, Cambodia. Since 2000, she has business selling groceries from her home to earn an income and is able to make about $2.50 each day. Her husband is a traffic policeman, and typically makes $2.50 a day. Two of their children are employed, and one is currently attending school. Meak S. is requesting a loan of $700 to expand her grocery’s inventory and the also to purchase rice for resale as well.

loans.use: To expand her grocery’s inventory

loans.name: Confiance Group

texts.fr:
Confiance est un regroupement de cinq (5) femmes du village de Kimparana de la préfecture de San (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mail). Vivant dans des familles traditionnelles élargies avec des coépouses et d’autres parents, elles ont en moyenne 40 ans. Toutes mariées, elles sont mères d’au moins 3 enfants chacune.
En plus de l’activité principale à savoir le commerce de condiments alimentaires, elles mènent d’autres activités qui vont de la fabrication et de la vente de boissons locales alcoolisées (tchapalo) et la vente du bois de chauffe.
Liées par des relations d’alliances et de parenté, les membres du groupe Confiance ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis deux ans. Elles sont à leur cinquième prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe), tous les précédents ont été remboursés sans difficulté.
Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter, une grande quantité de condiments alimentaires ( Oignons, tomates, Laye, Poivres etc….) afin de constituer un stock pour prévenir d’éventuelle rupture en cette période des récoltes champêtres. Les achats sont effectués à Ségou et à Bamako (capitale de la république de Mali) auprès des grossistes et sur commande. Les ventes sont effectuées à domicile, au marché de Kimparana et dans les foires des villages voisins à une clientèle généralement féminine.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen et mensuel de 50 000FCFA. qui servira essentiellement à augmenter la taille de leur activité.
texts.en:
"Confiance" is a group of five women averaging 40 years of age from the village of Kimparana in San Prefecture (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They live in traditional extended families with co-wives and other parents, are all married, and are mothers with at least three children each.

In addition to their principal business, namely commerce in condiments, they do work making and selling local alcoholic beverages (tchapalo) and selling firewood.

Linked by married and by blood, the members of the Confiance Group decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso loan program two years ago. They are on their fifth solidarity loan (group loan). Each of the preceding ones has been repaid without difficulty. The current loan will be used to buy a large quantity of condiments (onions, tomatoes, "laye", black pepper, etc....) in order to build up an inventory to prevent possible shortages during this harvest season. The purchases will be made in Ségou and in Bamako (Capital of Mali) from wholesale merchants and by special order. Sales are made out of the home, at the Kimparana marketplace, and at the fairs of neighboring villages, to customers who are generally women.

They each envision realizing an average monthly profit of 50,000 francs CFA, which will essentially serve to expand their business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy condiments to create an inventory

loans.name: Veng

texts.en: Veng C., 40, is married and lives with four children and her husband in Kampong Cham, Cambodia. She is a farmer who grows rice two times per year. First, she grows in raining season which is about 6-7 months. Then, she grows in dry season, which is about 3-4 months, to collect harvest. Farming is hard as the weather conditions in the past year have not been good. Actually, she makes less than one dollar each day. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver. He been doing this business since 2005 and is able to make $3 per day. All four of their children are students. Veng C. is asking a loan of $500 to purchase a good rice seed to grow next year.

loans.use: To purchase a good rice seeds.

loans.name: Ismah

texts.en:
Ismah O., 45, is a member of the Bugolo group with a business of buying ‘mukene,’ small silvery fish, from the fishermen in Kikondo and Busaana, using his bicycle as transport, for 10 years. He is married with 7 children of whom some are older and the others are still in school; also he takes care of 1 orphan.

Ismah O. is very proud of the trend that his business is taking after he joined his lending group whereby he now buys about 50 to 100 basins of fish, each at 7000 shillings; he sells them at Mbale district market once a week.

He is seeking a loan to be able to buy more basins of fish so that he can include Tororo district on his list of markets, hence selling to Mbale on Monday and Tororo on Friday. He is a businessman who has grown over the three years since he joined his lending group, taking loans from US$ 185, $610, $925, and he now needs a loan of US$ 1200 for his business expansion.

loans.use: for buying more basins of fish for business expansion

loans.name: Saumu

texts.en:
Saumu has been in business in Zanzibar since 2007. She sells both firewood and kanga, a local fabric used for clothing and household needs. By diversifying her business ventures she has been able to earn approximately $45 each month. She works from 8 a.m. to 9 p.m. every day. With her first loan from BRAC Tanzania, she will buy more inventory of both of her products so that she can increase her sales and profit.

Saumu is 25 years old, married, and has two children, ages 1 and 5.

loans.use: To buy more firewood and kanga for her businesses.

loans.name: Munira

texts.en:
Munira was born in 1949 and she lives in Makljenovac, a suburb of Doboj in Bosnia. She is a widow and lives with her one child. She receives 150KM per month from her late-husband's pension plan, which is equivalent to roughly $100USD. This is not enough income for her to survive, so she is dependent upon microfinance loans to invest in new business ideas that will help her to meet her most basic needs.

Her first two loans in 2004 and 2005 were used to purchase goats. Her third loan in 2006 was used to purchase a cow. Her fourth loan in 2007 was used to purchase food for the cow. She was able to repay each loan with the additional income that the animal generated.

She now requests a fifth loan from Women for Women International, in the amount of 600KM. She will use this loan to buy pumpkin seeds, which she will sell to spectators at soccer games in the fall.

loans.use: to buy pumpkin seeds to sell to spectators at soccer games

loans.name: Khem

texts.en: Mr. Khem K. is 56 years old and rents musical instruments for ceremonies such as wedding parties and other happy occasions. He has been running his business since 1999 and earns currently around $4 per day. His wife, Mrs. Khlor Phalla, 47, is a grocery seller and sells many kinds of products such as oils, cake, soap, and porridge, and so forth. They have five children, two of whom are married and the other three are single and live at home. The family lives in Prey Kuy Commune, Kampong Thom Province. To support his business, Khem is requesting a loan of $1100 to purchase more modern musical instruments for his business and to buy more groceries for his wife to sell. Mr. Khem's wife is pictured because he was not available.

loans.use: To buy musical instruments and groceries

loans.name: Lourn

texts.en: Lourn H., 59, is married and lives about 124 miles from Phnom Penh, Cambodia, in Kampong Cham. She typically makes US$3 from selling beef from her home. Her husband is a farmer who grows rice and many kinds of vegetables. On average, he makes less than one dollar each day. Lourn H. would like to take out a loan of US$1000 to purchase fertilizer, rice seeds, and bean seeds.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, rice seeds, and bean seeds.

loans.name: Teo

texts.en: N. Teo is a business lady with a retail shop in Jinja, Busaana Tongole village. Her shop has been in existence for eight years now and she says that with God she has been able to manage it well, to the point of being able to pay school fees for her children. Teo also has a small restaurant that was started by using profits and savings from her retail shop as well as another retail shop branch in Senyi. Because of the market there, she has plans to transform this branch into a wholesale shop. She is a widow with four orphaned children and takes care of seven other orphans from her friends and relatives. Her major challenge is paying school fees for all her children; this is why she works so hard plus having many businesses. For seven solid years, she has been with Pearl Microfinance taking loans of various small denominations, and they have helped her rise to her current stage.

loans.use: To buy more sugar, cooking oil, maize flour, and baking powder for her shop.

loans.name: Dakan (Le Destin) Group

texts.fr:
Les huit (8) membres du groupe Dakan de l’association Lolo du village de Kimparana (préfecture de San) sont toutes mariés avec une moyenne d’âge de 39 ans et 8 enfants. Elles vivent en générale dans des foyers polygames dans la préfecture de San, région de Ségou (quatrième région économique du Mali).
Liés par des relations de voisinage et de parenté, les membres du groupe Dakan font essentiellement le commerce des produits cosmétiques, de fruits et légumes. 
Dans le souci d’avoir des ressources financières complémentaires le groupe intégra le programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec lequel il est à son cinquième prêt de groupe (prêt solidaire). Tous les prêts précédents ont été remboursés sans difficultés. Les prêts précédents ont permis d’augmenter la taille des activités et de fidéliser la clientèle.
Le groupe compte acheter, 20 cartons de produits cosmétiques de différentes sortes et une grande quantité de fruits et légumes. Pour les fruits et légumes elles s’approvisionnent sur place au marché de Kimparana auprès des forains ou producteurs venant des villages environnants. Quant aux produits cosmétiques l’achat se fait à Bamako (capitale de la république du Mali) auprès des grossistes. 
Les produits sont vendus à domicile, au marché de Kimparana et dans les foires des villages voisins à une clientèle généralement féminine.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice de 50.000 FCFA qui leur permettra d’aider les conjoints à supporter les charges familiales et d’augmenter le fonds de commerce.
texts.en:
The eight members of the group Dakan (meaning "destiny") of the Lolo association in the village of Kimparana (San Prefecture) are all married and average 39 years of age and eight children. They generally live in polygamous households in the Ségou region (fourth administrative region of Mali). Linked by ties of community and blood, the group members essentially do commerce in cosmetics, fruit, and vegetables.

Concerned about supplementary financial resources, the group joined the loan program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with which the members are on their fifth group loan (solidarity loan). All of the preceding loans have been repaid without difficulty. The preceding loans enabled them to expand their business and to earn the loyalty of their customers.

The group intends to buy 20 boxes of cosmetics of different types and a large quantity of fruit and vegetables. For these, they get their supplies locally at the Kimparana marketplace from market vendors or producers coming from surrounding villages. As for the cosmetics, the purchases are made iin Bamako (capital of Mali) from wholesalers. The goods are sold out of the home, at the Kimparana marketplace, and in the fairs of neighboring villages, to customers who are generally women.

The group members each envision realizing a profit of 50,000 francs CFA that allows them to assist their spouses in supporting the family and to increase their working capital.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cosmetics, fruit, and vegetables

loans.name: Saber

texts.en:
This is Saber. He is 35 years old, married, but he still doesn't have any children and he is still a student in the university. He is studying engineering; this is his last year of studying. He lives with his family in Shewa Nangarhar province. He is a very intelligent young man.

Saber has a one brother and two sisters. They live in his village but his house is small and he wants to build some rooms onto his house because his brother wants to get married. There is no room for him, therefore he has decided to request a 50,000AF (US$ 1,075) individual loan so he can solve his problems.

So he thought a lot. Finally, he requested a Kiva loan that changes lives. He wants Kiva lenders to give him an individual loan for 24 months. With this money he will buy materials to build an all-purpose room and a bathroom. He says many thanks in advance.

loans.use: buying materials for construction

loans.name: Joy

texts.en:
Joy T., 34, has a retail shop selling new clothes and bags of various types on Kaaki road in Jinja. For 10 years, she has operated the shop and this is her 3rd year getting loans from Pearl Microfinance. She is married with 2 children in school and she cares for 2 step-children.

With her previous loans, Joy has been able to transform her shop in such a way that it now offers a variety of clothes and bags that was lacking before the loans. And as a result, she has been able to increase her savings and capital with her continuous involvement in small loans and this has helped her with school fees, with providing food for her family and above all with making her loan repayments on time.

Joy is now seeking a loan to be able to stock more clothes and bags in her shop. In future, she wants to expand her business by opening up another branch selling more clothes, bags, shoes and cosmetics.

loans.use: to stock more clothes and bags in her shop

loans.name: Halima

texts.en:
Halima has been selling kanga and kitenge in Zanzibar for three years. "Kitenge" is the local fabric used to make dresses and skirt/top outfits for women in Tanzania. They often contain an elaborate pattern and many bright colors. Kitenge is slightly thicker than "kanga," which is a more casual fabric. Both are sold as rectangles of material, but kanga generally stays in this form instead of being tailored into a dress. Kanga is also brightly colored and patterned but it is used as clothing, baby slings, table cloths and the like.

Halima works from 7 a.m. to 9 p.m. daily. She is able to earn approximately $60 each month. She is 29 years old, married, and has a 2-year-old child.

loans.use: To buy more kanga and kitenge fabric for her business.

loans.name: Isma

texts.en:
Isma was born in 1963 and lives in Gračanica, a small village in Bosnia. She is married and lives with her two children, who are 15 and 23 years old. Her husband works in construction, but in order to support their family, Isma also does agricultural work from their home. She grows vegetables and raises two cows, selling milk and milk products to earn roughly 200KM/month. (The equivalent of $132 USD.)

Isma requests a loan of 1,000KM from Women for Women International to buy food for her cattle. This loan is vital for her, as rising food prices make it impossible for her to otherwise purchase the food to sustain the cows through the winter.

Isma is excited to report that one of her cows is pregnant. She plans to sell the newborn calf and hopes to make extra money from the additional milk produced by the mother.

loans.use: to purchase food for her two cows

loans.name: Annet

texts.en:
Annet K. is 47 years of age and a proud owner of a retail shop in Jinja, Napiya park lane. Annet has had various businesses over her time. First, she was into selling through a wholesale shop containing cosmetics, and then she joined farming, where she bought and supplied foods and beverages with a 'World Food' contract. This is when she had all of her produce stolen, amounting to 18 millions Uganda shillings, while she had a loan from Finance Trust.

She had a difficult time paying back her loan in time, but with the help of friends, she was able to complete the repayment. She resorted to opening a retail shop business that she still owns today. She has no plans of changing to another business, but would like to turn her retail shop into a wholesale shop if she can access enough capital.

Annet is married with seven children, of which three are still in school, and she also cares for three orphans. Her success is due to her determination, the way she manages her loans, and God’s blessings.

loans.use: To buy more goods like bread, ground nuts, maize flour, and cooking oil for her shop.

loans.name: Danaya (La Confiance) Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe danaya est un regroupement de sept femmes du   quartier Hamdallaye de la ville de Koutiala qui se sont connues à travers la fabrication de la pâte alimentaire locale le Soumbala. Elles ont en moyenne 38 ans, mariées et mères d’au moins 4 enfants et vivent dans le quartier Hamdalaye  dans la préfecture de Koutiala  région de Sikasso.
Travaillant dépuis 3 ans avec Soro Yiriwaso, les prêts sont passés de 50.000 FCFA au premier prêt à 150.000 FCFA pour le cinquième prêt. Elles mènent toutes la même  activité ( fabrication et vente du soumbala). En plus de cette activité elle font d’autres activités  tellesque le tricotage. 
Le prêt actuel sera utilusé pour acheter  des sacs de noix de néré. Ensuite les noix sont bouillis et pilés pour obtenir une pate noirâtre à laquelle des formes variées sont données (boule ou ovale). Cette production est vendue  au marché de koutiala et à Bamako( la capilale malienne). Elles comptent réaliser en moyenne 125 000 CFA. de bénéfice pendant la durée du prêt.. Une grande partie du bénéfice réalisé servira à payer les frais de scolarité des enfants et faire face aux  dépenses courante de la famille.   
Dans l’avenir elles comptent approvisionner d’autres localités du Mali surtout celles de Gao et de Kidal.
texts.en:
Danaya is a group of seven women of the Hamdallaye district in the city of Koutiala (in Koutiala Prefecture in the Sikasso region). They know each other through the making of the local "pâte" (typically a cooked mash of grain, seeds, or nuts, formed into a ball and eaten with the fingers) called "soumbala". They average 38 years of age. They are married and the mothers of at least four children.

Working for three years with Soro Yiriwaso, the loans have gone from 50,000 francs CFA for the first loan to 150,000 francs for the fifth loan. The group members all do the same work (making and selling soumbala). In addition, they have other work, such as knitting.

The current loan will be used to buy sacks of néré nuts. Next, the nuts are boiled and pounded to obtain a dark paste, which is made into various shapes (balls or ovals). The product is taken to the marketplaces in Koutiala and in Bamako (capital of Mali).

The group members intend to realize an average profit of 125,000 francs CFA for the duration of the loan. A large portion of the profits will serve to cover the school fees of the children and to cope with the typical family expenses. In the future, the members will get their supplies from other places in Mali, especially from Gao and Kidal.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sacks of néré nuts to make soumbala.

loans.name: Edison

texts.en:
Edison T., 33, is a member of the Tuwoda group in Kamwokya. He is married with 5 children, all in school. He has a tailoring business where he works with his wife and together they make “bitenge” traditional wear for sale. He started by getting small loans for his business and over time, he has been able to develop his business.

His wife has started teaching young girls the same trade by teaching sewing skills, independence and self-esteem, as it is very good for them to have a skill if they don't get formal education, so as to avoid being very vulnerable. The length of the girls' stay with Edison’s wife will depend on how quickly they can grasp what is taught to them and this determines their fees.

Recently, Edison opened up another store in Kisenyi Bus Park in the middle of Kampala city for his business expansion. The two shops will help to better Edison’s family’s future.

loans.use: To buy more bitenge textile for his two shops.

loans.name: Fatma

texts.en:
Fatma has been selling charcoal in Zanzibar since 2006. Charcoal is the primary fuel used to cook food in Tanzania as few families own ovens or stoves. Fatma works from 8 a.m. to 9 p.m. every day and earns a profit of approximately $100 each month. She will be using her first loan from BRAC Tanzania to buy more charcoal so that she can increase her sales.

Fatma is 26 years old, married, and has two children, ages 3 and 5.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal to sell in her shop.

loans.name: Borka

texts.en:
Borka was born in 1959 and she lives in Doboj, a town in Bosnia. She is married and her husband works in a textile factory. While Borka does not have children, she runs a small daycare center from their home. She receives 350KM/month for this work (the equivalent of roughly USD$230.) Her income, when combined with that of her husband, is barely enough to meet their most basic needs. To generate additional income, Borka hopes to start cleaning people's houses on the weekends.

Borka requests a loan of 1,200KM from Women for Women International, which she will use to purchase a high-quality vacuum cleaner. With this vacuum cleaner, she will start her second business: cleaning the houses of the wealthy in Doboj.

loans.use: To purchase a vacuum cleaner, which is needed before Borka can start working as a maid on the weekends.

loans.name: Godfrey

texts.en:
Godfrey Mbangirensi is married with three children and he takes care of 3 brothers and sisters. He owns a retail shop in Kamwokya that has been operational for 8 years ever since his relocation from Rukungiri, his home town. With the small loans that he started with, he has been able to make a much bigger retail shop out of it, has built his own house in Kamwokya and another back home, as well as providing for his children, sisters, and brothers.

He has been repaying his loan and now needs another loan to be able to buy more sugar, salt, soap, and cooking oil for his shop so that it can bring in more profits. In the shop, he works with his wife but has a plan of opening up another shop for her to manage.

loans.use: to buy more sugar, salt, soap, and cooking oil for his shop

loans.name: Jurabek

texts.ru: Джураев Джурабек житель района Шахринау.Возраст 42 года,женат , имеет 3 детей.Клиент более 11 лет занимается куплей продажей фруктов и бахчевых культур(в сезон).Бизнес помогает ему содержать свою большую семью.На полученный кредит клиент хочеть увеличить денежный оборот.Планирует погасить кредит в течении 12 месяцев.
texts.en:
Jurabek J. lives in the Shahrinaw District. He is 42 years old, married, and has three children. For over 11 years he has sold fruits and melons (in season). The business helps him support his large family. He wants to use the requested loan to increase his working capital. The loan will be repaid in 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing working capital

loans.name: Ramzija

texts.en:
Ramzija was born in 1965 and lives in Doboj, a town in Bosnia. She is a widow with no children. She currently receives 300KM from the pension plan of her late-husband, which is equivalent to roughly $200USD. In a country where a quality vacuum cleaner costs 200KM, this pension income is barely enough for Ramzija to survive.

Ramzija requests a loan of 1,000KM from Women for Women International in order to buy chickens and food for the chickens. She hopes to raise them and re-sell them to her relatives and friends when they are adults. This is her first microfinance loan.

loans.use: to purchase chickens and food for chickens

loans.name: Muhayo

texts.en:
Muhayo is the mother of one adorable daughter. For almost four years, she has been selling dried fruits at the markets. In order to buy fruits, she goes to other cities which are far away from her house about twice a week and buys fruits there from people for a cheaper price. Then, she brings them home and dries them, which takes about a week. After that she sells them at the markets.

Now, everything is getting expensive, so she wants to borrow money to buy more fruits and offer them to her clients. This way, she can also earn more money to help her husband to support her family.

loans.use: To buy more fruits

loans.name: Istadoy

texts.ru: Абдуллоева Истадой жительница района Шахринау.Возраст  38 лет,замужем,имеет 4 детей.Клиентка занимается куплей продажей  лепешек.Этот вид деятельности помогает ей содержать  свою  семью .На полученный кредит  Истадой  хочет увеличить денежный оборот.Планирует  погасить кредит  в течении 12 месяцев.
texts.en:
Istadoy A. lives in the Shahrinaw District. She is 38 years old and has four children. Istadoy has a business selling flatbread. This work helps support her family. She wants to use the loan received to increase her working capital. The loan will be repaid over 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase working capital

loans.name: Soeurn

texts.en: Mrs. Soeurn C. P. is a villager in Taing Chrey Village in Kampong Cham Province. She is farmer who owns six hectares where she cultivates rice. In this plantation, she now faces an obstacle because her field is infertile. To deal with this problem, she decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer to make her crop more productive. Her husband, Mr. Chham Sophal, is a fisherman who makes a small income to support the household. Mrs. Soeurn C. P. is 26 years old and the mother of three children, two of whom attend the local school while the other is too young for school. Her husband is on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Hamida

texts.en:
Hamida has been selling juice and water in Zanzibar for three years. She begins work at 7 a.m. every morning and earns approximately $45 in profit each month. She intends to use her first loan from BRAC Tanzania to buy more juice and water so that she can increase sales and profit at her shop.

Hamida is married and has five children, ages 18, 16, 11 and 3 years old and one infant of 2 months.

loans.use: To buy more juice and water to sell in her shop.

loans.name: Hursan

texts.ru: Рузиева Хурсан жительница района Шахринау.Возраст 54 года, замужем , имеет 5 детей.Образование среднее. Клиентка занимается куплей продажей фруктов.Она торгует на центральном рынке города Регар.Занимается бизнесом уже 35 лет.Бизнес является основным источником дохода ее большой семьи.Так как муж клиентки пенсионер.На полученный кредит хочет закупить больше  качественного  товара.Планирует погасить кредит в течении 12 месяцев.
texts.en:
Hursan R. lives in the Shahriaw District. She is 54 years old, married, and has five children. She completed secondary education. This entrepreneur sells fruit at the central market in the city of Regar. She has been in this business for 35 years already. The business is the primary source of income for her large family, since her husband is retired. She wants to use the loan to buy higher quality produce. The loan will be repaid over 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of goods

loans.name: Tuwoda Women's Group

texts.en: N. Jennifer is a 28-year-old hard-working young lady and mother of three. For eight years now, she sells all types of fresh fruits and produce such as yellow bananas, mangos, paw paws, pineapples, apples, oranges, pears, passion fruit, and Matooke that she sells to her customers in Kamwokya. She started very small with a few pieces of fruit for sale but now sells a variety, including matooke (green bananas). This has greatly increased her sales, hence more profit. She needs another loan to be able to buy more fruits and sacks and bunches of matooke for sale to her ever-expanding customer base. The benefits that have come from getting loans from Pearl Microfinance range from her family’s upkeep, community socialization, children’s welfare plus business development, expansion and continuity.

loans.use: To buy more fruits, vegetables, sacks and bunches of matooke for sale

loans.name: Kimsim

texts.en: Mrs. Kimsim H. is 50 years old and sells vegetables in the market. She has been selling vegetables for ten years and can earn approximately $6 per day. Normally, she buys vegetables from growers and sells them in the market for a profit. She is married to Mr. Chruy Nong, 49, who is a farmer. They have five children, one of whom is married and the other four are single; two daughters are employed as garment workers in Phnom Penh, both earning $210 per month. The family lives in Thmar Poun Commune, Kampong Cham Province. Now she lacks capital for her business and would like to request a loan of 2,000,000 ($500 USD) to purchase vegetables and fruits to sell.

loans.use: To buy fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Mrs. En Leng Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of eight members in Khvet Village in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia.

Mrs. En L. has been selected by the members to be the village bank president. She is a pig breeder who raises three pigs. Mrs. En L. is 28 years old and the mother of a two year old and a three-month-old baby.

Because her business is going well, she wants to expand it, so she is asking for a loan to buy more piglets to breed. Her husband, Mr. Bi Sat, has a plot of land where he cultivates rice to earn a living. 

Mr. Uth H. and Mr. Tol R. did not coM. to the loan meeting where the photograph was taken, but their wives were there, so they appear in the photograph.

This is a village bank loan consisting of mainly end-of-term (EoT) loans. Seven members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly-payment loans. Group members who have an EoT loan are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. 

Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on tiM.. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy more piglets for breeding.

loans.name: Oisha

texts.en:
Oisha has been a widow for many years. In order to support her three children, she has been selling dried fruits. It is very tiring and hard work. Her business requires that she go to a distant city early in the morning, purchase fruits for cheaper price, return home and then begin drying them, which takes about a week. When the fruits are ready, she sells them at the market where she has many clients.

Oisha wants to use a loan to buy more fresh fruits. She can then offer more dried varieties to her clients.

loans.use: Buying more fruits to dry for resale

loans.name: Orifjon

texts.ru: Маджидов Орифджон житель района Шахринау .Возраст 37 лет, женат , имеет 1 ребенка. Образование средне-специальное, по специальности шофер.Клиент занимается частным извозом на собственной автомашине. Имеет опыт в бизнесе более 8 лет. Эта деятельность является основным источником дохода его семьи.На полученный кредит Орифджон хочет отремонтировть машину.Планирует погасить кредит в тчении 12 месяцев
texts.en:
Orifjon M. lives in the Shahriaw District. He is 37 years old, married, and has a child. He was trained as a driver through his secondary vocational education. He works as a private taxi driver, using his own vehicle. He has over 8 years of experience in this business. This work is the primary source of income for his family. Orifjon wants to use a loan to make repairs on his vehicle. He will repay the loan over 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Automobile repairs

loans.name: Mariam's Group

texts.en:
N. Mariam is proud to be the only Hajjat in the group of Nkokonjeru. Her business is buying and selling mukene (small silvery fish) from Nkombwe landing site in Ngogwe Sub County for eight years now. Before this business, Hajjat used to sell tomatoes and onions, but because they were perishables, she was always losing money.

With the small fish, it’s a matter of drying them properly; do so and they will last for a very long time. Mariam says the prices of the fish keep fluctuating depending on the season, and this influences her selling price. Mariam is a widow who cares for five orphans and three other orphans (her stepchildren), who are all in school; two are in candidate classes.

Since she started getting loans, Mariam has managed to care for her family and has bought some land for farming hence reducing the cost of buying everything including food. She has also bought some goats which she sells and has a dream of buying a cow (a good one costs about one million Uganda shillings). A cow would provide milk for sale, and Mariam hopes this will happen for her and her family soon. She plans to buy more small fish for her stock once she has access to a loan.

loans.use: To buy more fish for resale

loans.name: Kumrinisso

texts.ru: Суюнова Кумриниссо жительница района Шахринау.Возраст  45 лет, замужем , имеет 4 детей.Образование средние. Клиентка более 12 лет занимается куплей продажей овощей. Кумриниссо имеет торговую точку на местном рынке. Клиентка закупает оптом у крестьян овощи и реализует их в розницу.В данный момент клиентка хочет увеличить ассортимент торговой точки.Планирует погасить кредит в тчении 12 месяцев.
texts.en:
Kumrinisso S. lives in the Shahrinaw District. She is 45 years old, married, and has four children. She has a secondary education. For over 12 years this entrepreneur has been selling vegetables. Kumrinisso has a stall at the local market. She buys vegetables wholesale from small farms and sells at retail prices. Now she would like to expand the variety of produce offered at her stall. The loan will be repaid over 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Expand market stall inventory

loans.name: Ramzan

texts.en: Ramzan baji is the wife of M. and lives in a city named Kasur, Pakistan. Kasur city is famous for its sweetmeats and holy places. She is the mother of three children: one son and two daughters. None of her children goes to school. She owes a six-room brick house and has been living in it for the last 10 years. Ramzan baji’s husband has a plastic-bag-selling business. He buys bags from a scrap shop and sells to different factories. The factories melt the bags and make plastic utensils (pots, dinner sets). He has been in this business for the last 7 years. Ramzan baji is a housewife and prefers to do household work and take care of her family. Ramzan baji is applying for a loan to buy more plastic bags to resell.

loans.use: To buy more plastic bags to resell

loans.name: Salomat

texts.ru: Бакирова Саломат жительница города Вахдат.Возраст 38 лет, замужем,имеет 3 детей.Образование среднее,клиентка занимается производством  лепешек и самбусы.Она имеет небольшой цен на местном рынке города Вахдат.В данный момент очень вырос спрос на ее продукцию.Саломат решила увеличть производство хлебо-булочных изделий.Поэтому решила взять кредит сроком на 3 месяца.
texts.en:
Salomat B. lives in the city of Vahdat. She is 38 years old, married, and has three children. She has a secondary education. This entrepreneur produces flatbread and sambusa (Tajik savory pastries), which she sells at a low price in the local Vahdat market. Recently demand for her products has been growing significantly, so Salomat decided to increase her production of baked goods using a 3-month loan.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of flour

loans.name: Swallehah

texts.en: Swallehah baji is the wife of M. A. and lives in a city named Kasur, Pakistan. Kasur city is famous for its sweetmeats and holy places. She is the mother of six children. Swallehah baji owes a four-room brick house and has been living in it for the last 20 years. Swallehah baji’s husband has a power loom machine and he manufactures clothes and sells them in the market. He has been in this business for the last 40 years. Swallehah baji is a housewife and prefers to do household work and take care of her family. She is applying for a loan to buy thread to make more clothes and to sell so they earn a good profit.

loans.use: To buy thread to make clothes

loans.name: Seema

texts.en: Seema baji is the wife of L. A. and lives in a city named Kasur, Pakistan. Kasur city is famous for its sweetmeats and holy places. She is the mother of six children: two daughters and four sons. Her daughters and her younger son are enrolled in a local school in her neighborhood. She has been living in this city for the last 40 years. Seema baji’s husband manufactures clothes and sells them to different markets. He has been in this business for the last 26 years. Seema baji is a housewife and prefers to do household work and take care of her family. She is applying for a loan to buy thread to manufacture more clothes to sell in market.

loans.use: To buy thread to make clothes

loans.name: Gulsanam

texts.ru: Хамзаева Гулсанам жительница города Вахдат.Возраст 30 лет, незамужем,образлвание среднее.Клиентка имеет небольшую столовую на рынке  района Вахдат. В данный момент она хочет  закупить больше  овощей,масла и муки. Расширив бизнес,она сможет получать больше дохода.Планирует погасить кредит в течении 3 месяцев.
texts.en:
Gulsanam H. lives in the city of Vahdat. She is 30 years old, unmarried, and has a secondary education. This entrepreneur has a small cafeteria in the Vahdat district market. She wants to buy more vegetables, oil, and flour. Expanding her business will increase her profits. The loan will be repaid over three months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of foods for cafeteria

loans.name: Ghulam Fatima

texts.en:
Ghulam Fatima baji is the wife of M. A. and lives in a city named Kasur, Pakistan. Kasur city is famous for its sweetmeats and holy places. Ghulam Fatima baji is the mother of three sons. Her younger sons are enrolled in a local school in her neighborhood. She owns a four-room brick house and has been living in it for the last 28 years.

Ghulam Fatima baji's eldest son makes embroidered clothing to order and also sells his clothes at the clothing market. He has been in this business for the last 10 years. Ghulam Fatima baji is a housewife and helps her son in the making of embroidered dresses. She is applying for a loan to buy materials (colored thread, beads, and cloth) to make more clothes to sell in the market and to complete the orders of customers.

loans.use: To buy material to make embroidered dresses

loans.name: Mukima

texts.en: Mukima has a very big family: she has 6 kids! Her husband left to go to Russia to get a better paying job. So Mukima had to do something to support her family and help her husband. She started with buying cattle, mostly cows, fattening them and selling them at the markets. She has been doing this for more than 10 years already and by this time, she has become really good in this. Now, in these days, everything is so expensive and to buy more cattle, she needs more money, so she decided to borrow money to expand her business.

loans.use: Expanding her business

loans.name: Gavhar

texts.en:
Gavhar is a divorced mother of two adorable children. Since she must support the family, Gavhar works hard selling groceries to earn enough money to pay her expenses. By being very polite and nice to everybody, she has many customers.

Gavhar wants a loan so she can buy more grocery products and offer them to her clients.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory of grocery products

loans.name: Khadija

texts.en:
Khadija has owned a beauty salon in Zanzibar since 2007. She works at her salon every day from 9:00am to 9:00pm and earns a profit of approximately $20 each month. One of the services most requested at her salon is braided hair extensions for women. She intends to buy more extensions so that she can meet her clients' demands.

Khadija is 29 years old, married, and has two children, aged 2 and 6.

loans.use: To buy more products for use in her salon.

loans.name: Rasul

texts.en: Rasul J. has been a taxi driver for many years and is known in his town for being a fast but safe driver.  As a result he has acquired many regular clients and his business has prospered.  However, recent increases in the price of petrol have motivated him to convert his car to natural gas, which will save him money for fuel and allow him to offer his services for cheaper.  Therefore, Rasul is requesting a loan of $750, which he will use to purchase a gas canister to run his car.

loans.use: Purchasing gas canister for his car

loans.name: Fadila

texts.en:
Fadila was born in 1954 and she lives in a suburb of Gračanica, in Bosnia. She is divorced and has an adult son, but she lives alone. She raises and re-sells chickens, for which she earns about 200KM/month. This is equivalent to roughly USD$132, and is barely enough for her to survive.

Fadila hopes to start raising cattle. She requests a 1,000KM loan from Women for Women International, which she will use to purchase one cow. She hopes to sell milk and milk products in order to supplement her current income so that she can cover her basic needs.

loans.use: To purchase one cow.

loans.name: Refija

texts.en:
Refija was born in 1951 and lives in a suburb of Gračanica in Bosnia.  She is married without children.  Refija raises cattle and earns roughly 350KM/month by selling milk and milk products.  (The equivalent of roughly $230USD.)  

In the past, Refija hoped to get a contract with a milk factory, but was unable to do so.  She now considers this to be a blessing, as the milk factory reportedly exploits its workers.  By selling milk and milk products to her friends and neighbors, she earns a much higher margin and has more control over her work.

Refija requests a 1,000KM loan from Women for Women International, which she will use to buy a new calf.  She will raise the calf into adulthood and earn additional income from its milk.  This is her second loan; the first was also used to buy a cow (pictured) and was paid back successfully.

loans.use: To purchase a cow.

loans.name: Hanifa

texts.en:
Hanifa baji is the wife of N. A. and lives in a city named Kasur, Pakistan. Kasur city is famous for its sweetmeats and holy places. She has been living in this city for the last 40 years. Hanifa baji is a housewife and helps her husband in his business.

Her husband has a power loom on which he manufactures clothes; he sells them in various markets. In particular, he makes bedsheets and charges Rs. 500 to 600 per bedsheet. Hanifa baji's son is also involved in this business. He learnt this art from his father. Hanifa baji is applying for a loan to buy thread so that her son can make more bedsheets and clothes and can earn a good profit.

loans.use: To buy thread to weave clothes and bedsheets

loans.name: Siti

texts.en:
Siti B. has had a bakery in Zanzibar for 20 years. Working everyday from 7:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m., assisted by her children, she bakes cakes, bread, rolls, and other similar items, earning approximately $160 each month. In order to increase her profit, Siti is applying for a loan, her third through BRAC Tanzania. Her previous two loans, both repaid on time, enabled her to buy an electric mixer and an oven, although she still likes to do much of her baking over coals.

Siti is 45 years old and has five children, ages 1.5, 11, 13, 16, and 18, and she also cares for five additional dependents. Her husband died two years ago. With the increased profits resulting from her third loan, she hopes to save enough to build a house several kilometers from her current home. She views this as a necessity because it is possible that her current home will be taken from her. As a Muslim, her husband had a second wife and his other wife may stake a claim on the house she is living in and evict her and her children.

loans.use: To buy ingredients in bulk to increase her bakery's output.

loans.name: Allah Rakhi

texts.en: Allah Rakhi baji is a wife of M. and lives in a city named Kasur, Paksitan. Kasur city is famous for its sweetmeat and saint places. She has been living in this city for the last 40 years. Allah Rakhi baji’s husband has a power loom machine with which he manufactures clothes and bed sheets. His monthly income is $600. He has been in this business for the last 15 years. Allah Rakhi baji is a housewife and prefers to do household work. She is applying for a loan to buy thread to expand her husband’s business.

loans.use: To buy thread to make clothes and bed sheets

loans.name: Senada

texts.en:
Senada was born in 1979 and lives in Kalesija, Bosnia.  She is unmarried and lives with her parents.  She works as a tailor at a textile factory and earns 450KM/month.  (The equivalent of roughly $300USD.)  This is barely enough to meet her basic needs, so she also tailors clothing from her home at night with her friend's sewing machine.


Senada requests a 1,200KM loan from Women for Women International, which she will use to purchase her own sewing machine.  She hopes to start designing her own clothing and thinks that through fashion she can create a better life for herself.

loans.use: to purchase a sewing machine

loans.name: Abida

texts.en: Abida baji is a wife of M. and lives in a city named Kasur, Pakistan. Kasur city is famous for its sweetmeat and saint places. She owns a six room brick house and has been living in it for the last 18 years. Abida baji is involved in a dress making business. She buys clothes from the market and then she sews them and makes embroidery on them. When she completes dresses, she sells them in boutiques and charges good prices. She sells one dress for $18. Her monthly income is $600 to $700. She is applying for a loan to buy material (clothes, colored thread and sketches) to fulfill the orders of her customers.

loans.use: To buy material to complete orders

loans.name: Abdou Salam

texts.fr:
Ce habitant de la banlieue Kandé de Ziguinchor s'active dans le secteur de la peinture. Avec son activité, Abdou Salam D. gagne son quotidien et arrive à entretenir son épouse et ses 3 enfants
Il sollicite ce prêt pour acheter des seaux de peinture et faire face à l'exécution de ses marchés
texts.en:
This inhabitant of the Kandé suburb of Ziguinchor works as a painter. With his little business, Abdou Salam D. earns his daily bread and manages to support his wife and his three children.

He is requesting this loan to buy some pails of paint so that he can fill his work orders.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buying paint for his business

loans.name: Zubaida

texts.en:
Zubaida baji is the wife of N. A. and lives in a city named Kasur, Pakistan. Kasur is famous for its sweetmeat and religious places. Zubaida baji has been living in this city for 40 years. She is a housewife and prefers to do household work.

Zubaida baji’s husband manufactures clothes and bed sheets and sells them in the market. He earns approximately $600 to $800. Zubaida baji is applying for a loan to buy thread to make more clothes and bed sheets and thus be able to expand the business.

loans.use: Buy thread to make clothes and bed sheets to sell

loans.name: Sardaran

texts.en:
Sardaran baji is the wife of A. A. and lives in a city named Kasur, Pakistan. Kasur is famous for its sweetmeat and religious places. Sardaran baji has lived in this city for 45 years in the same four-room house, which she owns. Sardaran baji is a housewife and prefers to do household work.

Sardaran baji’s husband has a shoe shop and also sells CDs. He has had this business for the last 16 years. He has a good reputation in the community. Sardaran baji is requesting a loan to buy more shoes and CDs to increase their sales and expand the business.

loans.use: Buy more shoes and CDs to sell in the shop

loans.name: Bushra

texts.en: Bushra baji is the widow of S. A. and lives in a city named Kasur, Pakistan. Kasur city is famous for its sweetmeat and saint places. She owns a four room brick house and has been living in it for the last 20 years. Bushra baji’s brother lives with her and is involved in a cloth and rug making business. He has a power loom machine with which he makes clothes and rugs. He has been in this business for the last 15 years. He charges $10 to $12 for one rug. Bushra baji is a housewife and prefers to do household work. She is applying for a loan to buy more thread so that her brother is able to make more rugs and to sell them in the market to earn a good profit.

loans.use: To buy more thread to make rugs and clothes

loans.name: Bushra

texts.en: Bushra baji is the wife of M. and lives in a city named Kasur, Pakistan. Kasur city is famous for its sweetmeat and saint places. Bushra baji is a housewife and prefers to do household work. Her husband has a factory in which he makes leather shoes and he sells in several shoe shops. He has been in this profession for the last 30 years. He learnt this art from his father. Bushra baji owns a two storey house and has been living in it for the last 40 years. She is applying for a loan to buy leather so that her husband can make more pairs of leather shoes to sell in the shoe shops.

loans.use: To buy leather to make more shoes

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Making batik clothing

loans.name: Zuhra

texts.en:
Zuhra was born in 1951 and lives in Gračanica, a small town in Bosnia. She is a widow and receives 396KM/month from her late-husband's pension plan. (The equivalent of roughly $260USD.) This is not enough income to meet her basic needs, so she also takes care of sick people at the local clinic, earning an additional 100KM/month.

At the clinic, Zuhra also takes care of her mother, who is in the photograph. Zuhra requests a 1,500KM loan from Women for Women International, to purchase supplies to take care of her mother and other patients. Her wish is to give her mother the best care available, to make her sickness easier to bear.

loans.use: to purchase medical supplies for a clinic

loans.name: Olga

texts.en:
This entrepreneur is Olga P.. She sells shoes in her home town of Nikopol. She started this business 9 years ago. Due to her unbelievable determination and stamina she managed to grow her trade within these past years. Currently, she has about $4,000 invested in inventory. Her income is about $2,000 a month. 

Olga has just opened a second store. She is hoping to get a loan of 5800 Grivnas ($1000 USD) to stock it with new clothing items. Olga is a skilled and experienced business woman who knows how to identify a problem and come up with a proper solution even in the most challenging situations. We believe Olga’s professionalism and willingness to go all the way to achieve her goals will help her persevere and repay this loan without any problem.

loans.use: To buy clothing to sell

loans.name: Ludmila

texts.en:
Ludmila runs a business selling clothing in two local markets in Nikopol. Her inventory includes knitted wear, socks, and other men’s apparel. Ludmila started her small venture 6 years ago. One of the biggest attractions of her kiosk is that she steadily increases her selection of goods. In addition, Ludmila is always willing to meet the needs of her customers, and she listens to them carefully when they express their preferences. Presently, she has $2,000 invested in inventory, and her monthly net profit is $200.

Ludmila is requesting a loan of 5500 Grivna to increase the assortment of merchandise in her kiosk. She is ready to take action and move forward with her business, implementing some of her aspirations and watching her business become more and more sustainable each day.

loans.use: Increase the assortment of merchandise

loans.name: Hajrija

texts.en:
Hajrija was born in 1959 and lives in Rainci Donji, a village near Kalesija.  She is married and has a 25 year old son, who is employed and continues to live with her.  Hajrija's husband has a steady job, but he earns just 450KM/month (roughly $300USD/month), which is not enough to support the family.  As a result, she grows vegetables and corn in the fields behind her house and sells the products to her neighbors to generate additional income.

Hajrija requests a loan of 1,200KM from Women for Women International to buy a cow.  This will be her first cow and she plans to sell its milk and milk products at the local market.  All additional income will be used to help meet the basic needs of her family.

loans.use: to purchase a cow

loans.name: Boubacar

texts.fr: Boubacar S. est un transporteur, il fait l'inter-urbain. Ce habitant de Tiléne sollicite ce crédit pour réhabiliter son véhicule. Son activité est rentable et il arrive à subvenir à ses besoins
texts.en:
Boubacar S. is an inter-urban transporter. He lives in Tiléne and is requesting this loan to repair and refurbish his vehicle. His business is making money and he manages to support himself.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: repairing and refurbishing his vehicle

loans.name: Rasema

texts.en:
Rasema was born in 1951 and lives in Tupković, a village close to Živinice in Bosnia. She is a widow and receives 300KM/month from her late-husband's retirement plan, which is the equivalent of roughly $200USD. She lives with her 19 year old daughter, who studies at a local university. The money from the retirement plan is barely enough to support their basic needs, let alone the cost of her daughter's education. For this reason, she sells vegetables from her garden and has used two loans to purchase cows (pictured), from which she sells milk and milk products.

Rasema is requesting a loan of 1,300KM from Women for Women International to purchase a third calf. She will raise the calf into adulthood and plans to sell its milk. She will also use the loan to help cover her daughter's school costs. Her wish is that her daughter finishes her education.

loans.use: to purchase a cow

loans.name: Amela

texts.en:
Amela was born in 1982 and lives in a suburb of Kalesija, an area known for its shepherds, farmers, and goat herders. Amela is married and her husband is employed, earning about 800KM/month (the equivalent of roughly $530USD). She has a two year old son and works in the home, taking care of her child and tending to a garden where she grows vegetables and corn for her family. She also has a cow, from which she sells milk and milk products to her neighbors.

Amela requests a 1,000KM loan from Women for Women International, which she will use to buy baby chickens and food for the chickens to survive the winter. She hopes that she can sell the chickens for meat to generate more income for her family, and also for her to feel more useful in the home. This is her first loan.

loans.use: to purchase baby chickens and food for the chickens

loans.name: Cruz Luciano

texts.es: El Sr. Cruz tiene 35 años de edad, habita en un barrio que se llama Villa Reconciliación  de los bomberos 6 andenes al norte, su esposa es comerciante vende frutas y ayuda a los gatos de la familia, el negocio de don Cruz es la venta de lubricantes y vulcanización, tiene diez años de estar en las ventas, el inicio con dinero que su mama le dio para que comenzara, luego ha ido invirtiendo con dinero que ha prestado a largo plazo en Afodenic. Con la solicitud de préstamos es para invertir en la compra de lubricantes y neumáticos nuevos para ofertar a su clientela. A largo plazo es poder comprar un compresor moderno y estantes para lubricante para que el cliente pueda ver sus productos con mayor visibilidad y captar más clientes
texts.en:
Cruz is 35 years old and h e lives in the region named «Villa Reconciliacion de los bomberos 6 andenes» north. His wife is a vendor of fresh fruits and she contributes to the family's finances. The business that Cruz runs is the sales of auto lube products. He has been selling these products for 10 years, a business he started with funds that were given to him by his Mom. He then acquired a series of loans from Afodenic and all funds were invested back in the purchase of lube products and new tires to offer his clients. His long term goal is to be able to purchase a modern compressor and shelving to organize his products. His clients will be able to browse the products and with greater visibility he will be able to gain more clients.


Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase lube products and tires.

loans.name: Deysi

texts.es: Sus aspiraciones desde muy joven tuvieron que ver con la venta de ropa, es por eso que Deysi es una excelente vendedora de estas sus prendas, tanto para adultos, como para niños, las cuales también, a veces, las deja al crédito. Tiene 37 años y 2 hijos, los cuales están estudiando, y a quienes quiere brindarles, por el momento, sus estudios, hasta que se decidan por una profesión ser. Su esposo pareja Máximo, trabaja independientemente, y está de acuerdo con todo lo que ella decide respecto a su negocio.  La meta trazada de Deysi, es crecer e implementar su negocio, complementarlo con algunos otros accesorios, pero para ello necesita de un capital  para lograr su objetivo. Apoyemos a la señora Deysi, madre talentosa, que se esfuerza arduamente por prosperar.
texts.en:
Her aspirations since she was very young had to do with clothing sales. It's for that reason that Deysi is an excellent salesperson of these clothing items, both for adults and children. Sometimes she sells on credit. She is 37 years old and has two children, both of whom are studying. For the moment she is focused on their studies until they decide on a profession. Her husband Máximo works independently and is in agreement with everything she does with respect to her business. Deysi's goal is to grow her business complementing it with some other accessories but in order to do that she needs business capital to reach her objective. Let's support Deysi, a talented mother, so that her hard work will allow her to prosper.

Translated from Spanish by Hugh Yarbrough, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase additional clothing to sell

loans.name: Maria

texts.es: Maria, de 31 años de edad, pertenece al banco comunal llamado “2 de Febrero”, se dedica a la venta de hielo desde hace ya tiempo, ella tiene dos hijos, que son la luz por la cual trabaja cada día, porque desea verlos, en un momento dado, profesionales. Su conviviente Pablo, quien trabaja junto con ella en este negocio, está de acuerdo con todo lo que se propone para la mejora y prosperidad de su labor. Venden al por mayor, de 350 a 450 pedazos de hielo al día, aun así, no les rinde una ganancia suficiente para el satisfacción de todas sus necesidades, ya que las máquinas hieleras le ocasionan gastos, por eso que necesita de un préstamo para comprar otra hielera, e incrementar sus ventas.  Apoya a la señora Maria, es trabajadora, no te defraudará.
texts.en:
Maria is 31 years old and belongs to the community bank call the "2nd of February," and has sold ice for a long time. she has two children, who are the light for which she works each day, because she wants to see them become professionals.
