Ainsi le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter à Lomé (la capitale togolaise) des tasses, des thermos, des glacières et des tissus wax (tissus appréciés en Afrique de l’ouest) en achat groupé. Très professionnelles dans le commerce, elles amènent des produits appréciés par les togolais (Dah rouge, le beurre de karité etc.…) et achètent au retour les articles cités ci-dessus. Les ventes se font à la maison ou au marché de San, de Kifosso et dans les villages environnants.

Elles comptent réaliser en moyenne 100 000 CFA. de bénéfice dont une partie sera utilisée pour payer la scolarité des enfants et faire face aux dépenses de santé.
texts.en:
The Sewa group consists of 5 women who are neighbors in the village of Kimparana, Prefecture of San, Ségou Region. They have an average age of 42, are married and the mothers of at least 6 children.

To expand the size of their businesses, the members decided two years ago to join the loan program of Soro Yiriwaso. The amount they are allowed to borrow has gone from 50,000 F CFA for the first loan to 100,000 F CFA for the third. They have various businesses such as selling kitchen utensils, clothing, and diverse merchandise. Thus, this loan will be used to buy (in Lomé, the capital of Togo) cups, thermos bottles, ice chests, and lengths of wax-print cloth (much appreciated in West Africa) as a group purchase. Very professional in their business dealings, they export items that the Togolese are fond of (red lentils, shea butter, etc.) and on their return, they buy the articles mentioned above. Their sales are made out of their homes or at the marketplaces of San, Kifosso, and in neighboring villages.

They expect to make an average of 100,000 CFA. in profit, of which a part will be used to pay school fees and deal with medical expenses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy various articles

loans.name: Hou

texts.en:
Hou P. is 51 years old and lives in the Siem Reap Province with his wife and their daughter. Both he and his wife, who is 49 years old, are farmers and have farmed since 1979. Each of them earn about a $1.25 per day. Their daughter, who is 18, is a grocer making about $10 per day. She contributes her income to the entire household's income.

Hou P. is requesting a loan of $600 to renovate his daughter’s grocery store in order to have more space to stock more items. In the future, he would like to expand their grocery stand further.

Hou P. is requesting a loan through Kiva’s field partner CREDIT – Micro Finance Institution. CREDIT-MFI has a repayment rate of 99.8% with a portfolio at risk 30+ at 0.33% (taken from their 2007 Annual report). CREDIT – MFI structures their non-agriculture Kiva loans with a declining balance interest rate. Agriculture loans are structured as balloon repayments with monthly interest rate payments and principle repayments at the end of the loan. To learn more about CREDIT-MFI please visit their Kiva Field Partner page or their website at

http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=9

http://www.credit.com.kh/

loans.use: To renovate his daughter’s grocery store

loans.name: Leat

texts.en:
Leat S. is 30 years old and lives in Siem Reap Province with her husband and their two children. She has been selling grocery products from her home since 2003 and earns about $3-4 per day. Her husband is a farmer who has been farming since 1999. Their children are aged 12 and 8 both go to school. Their household expenses are about $80 per month.

Leat S. is requesting a loan through Kiva’s field partner CREDIT – Micro Finance Institution. CREDIT-MFI has a repayment rate of 99.8% with a portfolio at risk 30+ at 0.33% (taken from their 2007 Annual report). CREDIT – MFI structures their non-agriculture Kiva loans with a declining balance interest rate. Agriculture loans are structured as balloon repayments with monthly interest rate payments and principle repayments at the end of the loan. To learn more about CREDIT-MFI please visit their Kiva Field Partner page or their website at

http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=9

http://www.credit.com.kh/

loans.use: Purchase a motor-bike to use for her business and for personal transportation.

loans.name: Gulbibi

texts.en:
Gulbibi is a mother of 3 adorable kids. she is very businesslike woman. She has more than one business. So she sells clothes at the market, fattens cattle and sells them and also grows wheat. She is a very unusual woman. 
She wants to borrow money to expand her business and also for buying more cattle and fertilizers for growing wheat.
Unfortunately Gulbibi wasn’t at the market when the photo was taken so we took a picture of her son who helps her out in her business.

loans.use: To purchase another calf and more fertilizers.

loans.name: Nam

texts.en:
Nam C. is 44 years old and lives in Siem Reap Province with her husband and their four children. She has been making baskets since 1998 and sells them out of her home, earning about $2 per day. Her husband, Touch Rim, is 42 and has been working as a motor-bike taxi driver since 2000, earning about $3 per day. Their children are aged 22, 18, 17, and 11. Three of them work as gardeners, and the youngest goes to school.

Nam C. is requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase a motor-bike for her children to commute to work. This will help them get to their work quicker enabling them to earn more money.

Nam C. is requesting a loan through Kiva’s field partner CREDIT – Micro Finance Institution. CREDIT-MFI has a repayment rate of 99.8% with a portfolio at risk 30+ at 0.33% (taken from their 2007 Annual report). CREDIT-MFI structures their non-agriculture Kiva loans with a declining balance interest rate. Agriculture loans are structured as balloon repayments with monthly interest rate payments and principle repayments at the end of the loan. To learn more about CREDIT-MFI please visit their Kiva Field Partner page or their website at

http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=9

http://www.credit.com.kh/

loans.use: To purchase a motor-bike for her children to commute to work

loans.name: Ing

texts.en:
Ing T. S. is 44 years old and is a widow, living in Siem Reap Province with her four children. She has been selling clothes at the local market since 2005, and earns about $5 per day. Two of her children work with her in the market, and the other two go to school. Their household expenses are about $75 per month.

Ing T. S. is requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase more clothes to expand her inventory. This would attract more customers and hopefully help her family earn more.

Ing T. S. is requesting a loan through Kiva’s field partner CREDIT – Micro Finance Institution. CREDIT-MFI has a repayment rate of 99.8% with a portfolio at risk 30+ at 0.33% (taken from their 2007 Annual report). CREDIT – MFI structures their non-agriculture Kiva loans with a declining balance interest rate. Agriculture loans are structured as balloon repayments with monthly interest rate payments and principle repayments at the end of the loan. To learn more about CREDIT-MFI please visit their Kiva Field Partner page or their website at

http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=9

http://www.credit.com.kh/

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to expand her inventory

loans.name: Rehema's Group

texts.en:
Rehema has been selling beans and other raw lentils in Zanzibar for two years. Beans are a staple food in Tanzania because they provide much-needed protein and are less expensive than meat. Rehema is currently able to earn approximately $85 each month. She will be using her first loan from BRAC Tanzania to buy more inventory so that she can increase her sales and profit.

Rehema is 20 years old, married, and has one, 4-month-old child. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Fatma, Mwanaisha, and Salma.

loans.use: To buy more food items to sell

loans.name: Vannak

texts.en: Mrs. Vannak K. is a 45-year-old a rice farmer who earns about $1.50 a day. She is married to Mr. Sory Vin and has five children, all of whom live at home. Four of her children are in school. The family lives in Phteah Rung Commune, Pursat Province. Mrs. Vannak is applying for a loan because she would like to supplement her income by buying groceries for resale.

loans.use: to buy groceries to resell

loans.name: Phim

texts.en:
Phim R. is 53 years old, a widow, and lives in Siem Reap Province with her three children. She has been working as a grocer, selling goods out of her house since 2000, earning about US$ 3- 4 per day. Her three children aged 26, 23, and 17 all work. One daughter has her own business in Phnom Penh, the other daughter has a business making and selling desserts, and her son works in construction. 

Phim R.'s store is located at her house. The requested loan would help her increase her inventory and attract more customers.

Phim R. is requesting a loan through Kiva’s field partner CREDIT – Micro Finance Institution. CREDIT-MFI has a repayment rate of 99.8% with a portfolio at risk 30+ at 0.33% (taken from their 2007 Annual report). CREDIT – MFI structures their non-agriculture Kiva loans with a declining balance interest rate.  Agriculture loans are structured as balloon repayments with monthly interest rate payments and principle repayments at the end of the loan. To learn more about CREDIT-MFI please visit their Kiva Field Partner page or their website at 

http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=9

http://www.credit.com.kh/

loans.use: to purchase more products to sell

loans.name: Biryema's Group

texts.en:
Biryema has been selling charcoal and firewood in Zanzibar for 5 years. Both are common household items among Tanzanians as they are the fuel with which food is prepared. Few Tanzanians own an oven or stove. Biryema will be using her first loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her inventory so that she can increase her profit.

Biryema is 28 years old, married, and has two children, aged 3 and 5. She is currently able to earn a profit of approximately US$ 100 each month. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Kinunu.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and firewood for her business

loans.name: Ibadatoy

texts.ru: Каримова Ибодатой жительница района Гиссар. Возраст 51 года,замужем,имеет 4 детей.Образование среднее.Клиентка имеет небольшую торговую точку,на которой торгует растительным маслом.На доход от бизнеса она содержит семью.На кредит Ибодатой планирует закупить очередную партию масла у оптовых поставщиков.Погасит кредит в течении 12 месяцев.
texts.en:
Ibodatoy K. is a resident of Gissar region. She is 51 years old, married and has four children. Gissar has a high school education. This loan client has a small trade outlet, where she sells vegetable oil, and with the proceeds from this business she supports her family. With this loan Ibodatoy plans to purchase another batch of oil from the wholesale suppliers. She will repay the loan within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase her inventory

loans.name: Karima

texts.en: Karima is married and has three children.  In order to support her family, she travels over 150 miles each week to purchase shoes in bulk, which she resells in the market near her home at retail prices.  Although the distance is not too far, the roads are very bad and it takes two days to pick up the shoes and return back to her town.  In order to save time and travel expenses, Karima is requesting a loan of $1200, which will be used to purchase greater quantities of shoes on each trip to her supplier.

loans.use: To purchase greater quantities of shoes.

loans.name: Niso

texts.ru: Амирова Нисо жительница района Гиссар.Возраст 42  года,вдова, имеет 2 детей.Образование средне-специальное,по специальности инженер.Так как заработная плата очень маленькая,поэтому клиентка  более 4 лет занимается куплей продажей растительного масла.Бизнес является единственным источником дохода ее семьи.Муж клиентки умер.На кредит Нисо хочет увеличить денежный оборот.Планирует погасить кредит в течении 12 месяцев.
texts.en:
Niso A. is a resident of Gissar region. She is 42 years old, a widow and has two children. She attended a technical school, where she majored in engineering. Due to the fact that her salary is so low, for four years this loan client has engaged in the buying and selling of vegetable oil. This business has been the family's only source of income since the death of her husband. With this loan Niso wants to increase her working capital, and she plans on repaying the loan within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase working capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase greater quantities of clothes.

loans.name: Mohruhsor

texts.ru: Хисорова Мохрухсор жительница района Гиссар.Возраст  31 год,замужем,имеет 3 детей.Клиентка занимается куплей продажей детской одежды.Торгует на местном рынке района Гиссар.Иммет опыт в бизнесе более 6 лет. На кредит клиентка хочет закупить сезонную одежду. Планирует погасить кредит в течении  12 месяцев.
texts.en:
Mohruhsor H. resides in the Gissar region. 31-years-old, married and the mother of three children, she buys and sells children's clothing. She plies her trade at the local Gissar regional market, and has more than six years' experience in the business. Mohruhsor wants to purchase seasonal clothing with this loan, and plans to repay it within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of seasonal clothing

loans.name: Kimhouy

texts.en: Mrs. Kimhouy H. is 27 years old and makes a living breeding pigs for resale in Phteah Rung Commune, Pursat Province. Normally, she buys piglets and raises them for three or four months and can earn approximately $2 per day. Kimhouy is married to Mr. Sen Sarorn, 32, who teaches in a secondary school. She has two children, both of whom are in school. Mrs. Kimhouy would like to expand her business, and needs a loan of $500 to buy more piglets to raise and feed for them to eat.

loans.use: to buy more piglets to raise and feed for them

loans.name: Sohibjamol

texts.ru: Гуломова Сохибджамол жительница района Гиссар.Возраст 42 года,замужем,имеет 4 детей.Клиентка имеет небольшую торговую точку на местном рынке.Она закупает у оптовых поставщиков женскую одежду и реализует ее в розницу.На прибыль от торговли содержит семью.На кредит планирует закупить товар ,погасит кредит в тчении 12 месяцев.
texts.en:
Sohibjamol G. resides in the Gissar region. 42-years-old, and married with four children, she has a small trade outlet in the local market. She purchases women's clothing wholesale and sells it retail. With the profit from this trade Sohibjamol supports her family. She plans to use the proceeds from this loan to purchase merchandise, and will repay the loan within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of seasonal merchandise

loans.name: Bimize

texts.en:
Bimize H. has been selling clothes and perfume in Zanzibar for 15 years. She is able to earn a monthly profit of approximately $90. She is taking out her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more inventory for her shop and increase her profit.

Bimize is 35 years old, married, and has four children, aged 16, 14, 11, and 3-and-a-half.

loans.use: To buy more clothes and perfume to sell in her shop.

loans.name: Rukhsana's Group

texts.en:
Rukhsana baji is the wife of L. A. and lives in a historical place named Yadgar, in the city of Lahore, Pakistan. Rukhsana baji owns a two-room brick house, and has lived there for the last 27 years. She is the mother of seven children: six sons and one daughter. Her elder son drives his own auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Two other sons drive a rented auto-rickshaw. Her fourth son has a business selling clothes. The others are enrolled in a local school in her neighborhood. Rukhsana baji’s husband drives a truck. He carries loads of fruits and vegetables and delivers them in different places. Rukhsana baji is a housewife and prefers doing household work and taking care of her family. She is applying for a loan to repair her son’s auto-rickshaw.

She has several other members in her loan group. Tasleem baji requests a loan to buy jewelry to resell. Bushra baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw. Maryam baji requests a loan to buy plastic beans to make boxes for keeping bundles of threads.

loans.use: Repair an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle)

loans.name: Verica

texts.en: Verica Ćustić is 35 years old and comes from the town of Derventa. She is a widow and raises her children alone. Both her children are school-aged. Verica is employed in a local shoe factory but this job does not pay enough to support her family, so she also works at home. She designs and prints price lists, diplomas, promotional materials, etc. She started by making cards for her children and they were good, so she decided to offer her services to other people. Her little business runs well but she thinks that it can be better. So, Verica requests a loan of 1000 KM ($675 US) to buy additional supplies for her computer, a new scanner, and a printer. In this way she will provide a better life for her family.

loans.use: To buy printing supplies for her computer

loans.name: Nasreen's Group

texts.en:
Nasreen baji is the wife of G. N. and lives in a historical place named Yadgar of the city Lahore, Pakistan. She has been living in this place for the last 31 years. Nasreen baji’s husband lives in Saudi-Arabia. She is the mother of one son, who wants to start a business. Presently, he works in an electrical supplies shop. He wants to buy a “pick up” vehicle for loading purposes. Nasreen baji is a housewife and prefers to do household work. She is applying for a loan to buy a “pick up” vehicle so that her son can start this business and earn good profit.

She is joined in her loan group by a few members. Farida baji wants a loan to buy tools to make electric switches to sell. Abida baji wants a loan to repair her auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Nargis baji and Rozina baji each want a loan to buy iron to resell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy a "pick up" vehicle

loans.name: Matluba

texts.ru: Кобилова Матлюба жительница города Вахдат.Возраст 41 год,замужем , имеет 4 детей.Образование среднее.Матлюба более 12 лет торгует на рынке города Вахдат.Она торгует женской обувью и одеждой.Имеет доход на который содержит свою семью.В данный момент клиентка хочет увеличить товарооборот.Планирует погасить кредит в течении 12 месяцев.
texts.en:
Matluba K. is a resident of the city of Bahdat. She is 41 years old, and married with four children. Matluba has a secondary school education and for more than 12 years has traded at the Bahdat city market. She deals in women's shoes and clothing, and the income supports her family. At present, Matluba wishes to increase her sales. She plans to repay the loan within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase sales

loans.name: Nikolina

texts.en: Nikolina S. was born in 1986 and comes from the town of Derventa. She is single and works in a local store as a sales person. Nikolina earns 400 KM monthly from her work in the store, and she earns extra income from her business at home. She lives with her mother, and they grow and sell flowers. They like their little business because it provides them with income that helps to improve their living conditions. They want to expand their business by providing more kinds of flowers. So, Nikolina is requesting a loan of 1500 KM ($1000 USD) to buy flower plants. Nikolina and her mother have enough flowers for the clients in their neighborhood, but with more flowers, they will be able to sell flowers in the local market also.

loans.use: To buy flower plants

loans.name: Farida's Group

texts.en:
Farida baji is the wife of M. A. B. and lives in a historical place named Yadgar in the city Lahore, Pakistan. She owes a two-room brick house and has been living in it for the last 35 years. She is the mother of four children: two sons and two daughters. Her sons work in a medical store as salesmen. Her elder daughter is in 8th standard. Her younger daughter is in 7th standard.

Farida baji’s husband is an electrician by profession. Farida baji is a housewife and prefers to do household work and take care of her family. She is applying for a loan to buy medicines because her elder son wants to open his own medical store.

She is joined in her loan group by several more members. Kosar baji and Bilquis baji each want a loan to buy garments to re-sell. Sabra baji wants a loan to buy spare parts for vehicles for her spare-parts shop. Nusrat baji wants a loan to buy goods (snacks, biscuits) for her canteen.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy medicines to open a pharmaceutical store

loans.name: Halim

texts.en: Halim D. is married and has three children.  While his wife works as a teacher at the local high school, Halim raises livestock and sells them for a profit.  He currently has two cows, and is hoping to fatten them through the winter and resell them in the spring.  In order to purchase the necessary forage and hay for his cows and further expand his business, Halim is requesting a loan of $1200.

loans.use: To purchase forage and hay for cattle.

loans.name: Zawadi's Group

texts.en:
Zawadi has been selling sheets and fabrics in a shop in Zanzibar since 2007. She works daily from 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. and is able to earn a profit of approximately $50 each month. She is now requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she may purchase more materials in bulk to sell for a greater profit.

Zawadi is 21 years old, single, and has no children. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Andia and Farida.

loans.use: To buy more sheets and fabrics for her shop.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: закуп сезонной одежды

loans.name: Zakia

texts.en: Zakia, who is 32 years old and married, has been selling food in her shop in Zanzibar for six years, working daily from 7:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m.  She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can stock more inventory and increase her profit.

loans.use: To buy more foods to sell in her shop.

loans.name: Rabia's Group

texts.en:
Rabia baji is the wife of Mr. A. and lives in a historical place named Yadgar in the city of Lahore, Pakistan. She resides in this place since last year. She is the mother of three children: one son and two daughters. Her daughters do household work. Rabia baji has a bookbinding business and her son helps her with the bookbinding. She has been in this business for the last 10 years. She is applying for a loan to buy material (thread, glue, and hard paper) to expand her business.

She is joined in her loan group by several more members. Ishrat baji wants a loan to buy spare parts for vehicles for her spare parts shop. Nosheen baji wants a loan to buy leather to make leather shoes. Nasreen baji wants a loan to buy seasonal fruit to re-sell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy material for bookbinding business

loans.name: Mavjuda

texts.ru: Тоджева Мавжуда жительница города Вахдат.Возраст 36 лет,замужем,имеет 3 детей. Образование среднее. Клиентка занимается куплей продажей женской одежды и нижнего белья.Имеет торговую точку на рынке « Хайр «.Имеет  опыт в бизнесе 10 лет.Доход от торговли помогает ее семье иметь все необходимое из продуктов питания.На кредит Мавжуда  хочет увеличить ассортимент торговой точки.Планирует погасить кредит в течении 12 месяцев.
texts.en:
Mavjuda T. lives in Vahdat. She is 36, married, and has three children. She has a high school education. The client works buying and selling women’s clothes and underwear. She has a shop in Hire Market. She has ten years of business experience. The income from her sales helps her family have enough to eat. By taking out a loan, Mavjuda wants to increase the variety of goods she offers. She plans to pay off the loan in twelve months.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase variety in inventory

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina has been selling food items in Zanzibar for four years. She works from 7:00am to 6:00pm daily and earns a monthly profit of approximately $110. Her business has grown nicely to this point, but she is taking out her first loan from BRAC Tanzania to increase the rate of growth and her profit by infusing her shop with more goods to sell.

Amina is 39 years old, married, and has 3 children, aged 7, 18, and 20.

loans.use: To buy more food items to sell.

loans.name: Habiba

texts.ru: Юсупова Хабиба жительница города Вахдат.Возраст 48 лет,замужем,имеет 5 детей.Клиентка занимается куплей продажей ткани.Имеет опыт в этом  бизнесе более 20 лет. Она покупает на оптовом рынке товар и реализует его в розницу.На полученный кредит Хабиба хочет закупить больше товара.Планирует погасить товар в течении 12 месяцев.
texts.en:
Habiba Usupava lives in the city of Vahdat. She is 48 years old, married, and has five children. This entrepreneur sells fabrics. She has over 20 years of experience in the business. She buys goods on the wholesale market and sells them retail. Habiba wants to use the loan to buy more goods. The loan will be repaid over 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of goods

loans.name: Hosiyat

texts.ru:
Назарова Хосиять, 1967 года рождения, замужем и у них 4 детей. Начала свой бизнес с продажи фруктов и овощей. У нее 10 лет опыта в этой деятельности. Она торгует на рынке «Дехконбозор» Гисарского района фруктами, овощами, куринные яйца, а в сезон продает рыбу, жаренную и сырую. У Хосият много постоянных клиентов, часто ее рыбу закупают оптом в столовые и пивные бары. Хосият хочет увеличить товарооборот и получить больше доходов. Покупает товар у дехкан, рыбаков  и поставщиков из Худжанда.
Хосият хочет получить с помощью программы Кива займ в сумме 1500 сомони чтоб закупить рыбы.
texts.en:
Hosiyat N. was born in 1967, is married, and has four children. She began her business by selling fruit and vegetables. She has ten years of experience. She trades in the Dekhanbozor market in Gissar, selling fruit, vegetables, chicken eggs, and, in season, fish both fried and raw. Hosiyat has many regular customers who frequently buy her fish wholesale for cafeterias and bars. Hosiyat wants to increase sales to make more money. She buys her goods from small farmers, fishermen, and suppliers from Khujand. Hosiyat wants to take out a loan through Kiva for 1,500 somoni in order to buy fish.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying fish

loans.name: Miumwa

texts.en:
Miumwa is 38 years old, married, and has two children. Miumwa has been preparing and selling food in Zanzibar for 5 years. She is able to earn approximately $175 each month.  

She is now seeking her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more ingredients and increase her sales and profit.

loans.use: To buy more ingredients to cook and sell food.

loans.name: Zulayho

texts.ru:
Орзикулова Зулайхо, 1949 года рождения, имеет 3 иждивенцев. Начала свой бизнес с продажи хлеба. В этом бизнесе уже 10 лет. Сейчас Зулайхо торгует на центральном рынке Гисара и у нее широкий ассортимент кондитерских изделий, таких как пряники, булочки, заварные, пирожные, печени. Также у нее в продажи имеются разновидность конфет и сахара. Покупает свой товар в кондитерских цехах и в оптовых магазинах Сафар – Центра. 
Зулайхо нужны средства для закупа сахара и она хочет получить займ в сумме 3000 сомони.
texts.en:
Zulayho O. was born in 1949 and has 3 dependents. She started her business by selling bread. She had been in this business for ten years. Now Zulayho trades in Gissar’s central market. She sells a wide variety of confections such as ginger cakes, rolls, choux pastry, cakes, and cookies. She also sells a variety of candies and sugars. She buys her goods in the confectionery shops in the wholesale shop Safar in the Shuhrat region. Zulayho needs to buy sugar, and she wants to take out a loan for 3,000 somoni for this.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying sugar

loans.name: Rahmonjon

texts.en: Rahmonjon O. is married and has eight children.  He lives with his entire family, as well as his parents, on a one-hectare property where he grows wheat and hay for his cattle.  Since he was very young, Rahmonjon has loved livestock and worked as a herder.  In order to expand his business he is requesting a loan of $1200, which will be used to purchase more forage and hay for his cattle.

loans.use: To purchase forage and hay for cattle.

loans.name: Saada

texts.en: Saada, 41 years old and married with three children aged one, two and eight, has been selling food items in Zanzibar since 2002.  Working from 8:00 a.m. to 10:00 p.m. everyday, she earns a profit of approximately $150 each month.  Saada is now requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can stock more inventory and increase her sales and profit.

loans.use: To buy more inventory for her food shop.

loans.name: Andrei

texts.en:
Andrei is a businessman from Nikopol. His business, selling clothing items, was started 2 years ago. One of the biggest attractions of his venture is affordable prices, which helps Andrei keep a favorable position among all the other clothes vendors who are his competitors.

Andrei has about $4,000 invested in his business. However, he looks into the future and sees wider horizons for development. One more thing that should be mentioned about this client is his impeccable credit history in Nadiya Ukraine. He hasn’t had a single late payment ever since he started using financial assistance from Nadiya Ukraine. Andrei is a true high achiever. We believe the current loan of 5800 Grivnas will help him move one step closer to his dream of becoming a leading and prosperous businessman in this sphere of trade.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory

loans.name: Khadija's Group

texts.en:
Khadija has been selling juice and fish in Zanzibar since 2002. She works daily from 8:00am to 9:00pm and earns a profit of approximately $45 each month. She is taking out her first loan from BRAC Tanzania to buy more stock for her shop to increase her sales and profit.

Khadija is 50 years old, married, and has two children, aged 18 and 25. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Mwajuma, who also owns a small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more juice and fish to sell.

loans.name: Marina

texts.en:
Marina P. is married and raising two kids. Her daughter is 16. Her son is only 4 months old. Not long ago after examination by the local doctors Marina found out her youngest child has some serious heart problems. Doctors suggested she should take him to Kiev for a surgery. Extra expenses connected with her son’s treatment made Marina work extra hard to provide for her personal needs and keep her business running along the way.

Marina has been a good client with Nadiya Ukraine. She has been running her business selling leather goods for 7 years. Presently, she has about $5,000 in inventory. Her monthly income is about $1,200. Marina has always dreamed of seeing her business sustainable and stable. At the moment her venture is facing some challenges as she cannot devote as much time to her business as before. However, she doesn’t want to give up and keeps an optimistic perspective. A loan of 2500 Grivnas will be repaid in two months.

loans.use: Keep her business running

loans.name: Mwasiti Bakari's Masasi Group

texts.en:
Mwasiti B., aged 24, is married with one son, four years old. She has a business selling prepaid phone credit, which she started in 2000. She operates stands in two areas: the city center and an area called Mbagala. She works with her husband from 7am to 7pm daily and is able to make a monthly profit of about $112.

Mwasiti has taken out two previous loans from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the loans to open the second shop in Mbagala and has paid the loans back successfully. She now hopes for a new loan to increase both businesses, but specificA. the one in Mbagala.

Mwasiti will share this loan with her loan group, Masasi, which totals 15 members. These members hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. In the picture, Mwasiti is in the second row from the front, on the left.

loans.use: To increase phone credit business

loans.name: Mwasiti Hamza's Kipunguni A Group

texts.en:
Mwasiti H., aged 30, is married with two children aged 12 and 9. She owns a shop in Kipunguni, where she sells kangas (Swahili sarongs) and vitenge (traditional Swahili fabrics). She started this business in 2007 and works daily from 8am until 8pm. She is able to earn a monthly profit of about $64.

This will be Mwasiti’s third loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the first two to increase the stock of her shop and has paid the loans back successfully. She now hopes for a new loan to expand her shop by purchasing ladies clothes and shoes to sell.

Mwasiti will share this loan with subgroup A of the Kipunguni group. The subgroup has 8 members, who run cafes and shops, and sell clothes. These members hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. In the picture, Mwasiti is in the front row on the right.

loans.use: To increase her shop's selection to include ladies clothes and shoes.

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha has been selling shoes in Zanzibar since 2005. She works from 8:00am to 6:00pm every day and earns a profit of approximately $85 each month. She is now taking out her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can expand her inventory and increase her sales and profit.

Asha is 35 years old, divorced, and has one 17-year-old child.

loans.use: To buy more shoes for her shop.

loans.name: Consolatha Mahagama's Kipunguni B Group

texts.en:
Consolatha M., age 40, is married with six children. She runs a business selling chicken and vegetables wholesale to shop owners in the city center. She started this business in 1996 and works daily from 1am until 8am. She is able to earn a monthly profit of about US$ 80.

This will be Consolatha’s fourth loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the loans to increase her business inventory. She now hopes for a new loan for the same purpose.

Consolatha will share this loan with subgroup B of the Kipunguni group. The subgroup has 7 members. These members hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. In the picture, Consolatha is in a red dress, second from the right.

loans.use: To increase inventory of vegetables and chicken

loans.name: Halima

texts.en:
Halima has been cooking food and selling miscellaneous food items in Zanzibar for ten years. She works daily from 7:00am to 7:00pm and earns a profit of approximately $50 each month. She is taking out her first loan from BRAC Tanzania in order to expand her inventory and increase sales.

Halima is 31 years old, married, and has no children.

loans.use: To buy more ingredients and food items to sell.

loans.name: Time

texts.en: Time, the mother of four children aged 1, 15, 20 and 24, sells a wide variety of products at her small shop, the most popular being fish, charcoal, and small snacks.  She has been in business in Zanzibar for four years and currently earns a profit of approximately $80 each month.  Now, Time is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can add more inventory and increase her sales and profits.

loans.use: To buy more inventory for her shop.

loans.name: Naima

texts.en:
Naima has owned a small shop in Zanzibar for three years. She stocks a variety of items including biscuits, detergent, water, and household utensils. She works daily from 7:00am to 6:00pm. Naima is now taking out her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she may expand her inventory and see a resulting rise in sales.

Naima is 30 years old, married, and has two children, aged 2 and 12.

loans.use: To buy more inventory for her small shop.

loans.name: Asia's Group

texts.en:
Asia baji is the wife of T. M. B. and lives in a historical place named Yadgar of city Lahore, Pakistan. She owns a two room brick house and has been living in it for the last 40 years. She is the mother of one son. Her son's name is Waseem and he reads in 5th standard. Asia baji’s husband has a rented motor-bikes business. He gives motor bikes to customers on rent and charge fees per hour. Asia baji herself is a housewife and prefers to do household work and take care of her family. She is applying for a loan to buy another motorbike for her husband’s rented bikes business.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Sarwar baji wants a loan to buy tools to make electric switches. Irshad baji wants a loan to buy a donkey cart for loading. Maryam baji wants a loan to buy iron to resell. Asia baji wants a loan to buy cosmetics to resell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy another motor bike

loans.name: Rahma

texts.en:
Rahma has been preparing and selling food in Zanzibar for one year. Through the snacks that she sells, she is able to earn a profit of approximately $55 each month. She is now requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania, which she will use to buy more ingredients, particularly oil and flour, so that she can increase her output and sales.

Rahma is 25 years old, married, and has one 8-year-old child.

loans.use: To buy more ingredients with which to cook food

loans.name: Suraiya

texts.en:
Suraiya baji is the wife of Mr. S. and lives in a historical place named Yadgar in the city of Lahore, Pakistan. She owns a two-room brick house, where she has lived for 30 years. She is the mother of two sons. Her elder son drives an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). The younger son is in kindergarten.

Suraiya baji’s husband drives a horse cart for deliveries. Unfortunately, his horse fell ill, and he can't use it for pulling the cart, because he treats the horse like his child. Suraiya baji is a housewife and prefers doing household work and taking care of her family. She successfully repaid her previous two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Suraiya baji requests a loan to buy another horse so that her husband can continue working and earning a profit.

loans.use: Buy a horse to pull the delivery cart

loans.name: Assane

texts.fr: ASSANE D. EST ROPIETAIRE D'UN MAGASIN DE QUINCAILLERIE AU QUARTIER MEDINA FAL DE THIES DEPUIS 18 MOIS. IL EST MARIE ET PERE DE 02 ENFANTS. IL COMMERCIALISE DU CIMENT, DU FER, ET DIVERS MATERIELS DE CONSTRUCTION.
texts.en:
ASSANE D. has been the owner of a hardware store in the MEDINA FAL district of THIES for 18 months. He is married and the father of two. He markets cement, iron, and various construction materials.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Commerce in hardware

loans.name: Saida

texts.en:
Saida, a 44-year-old mother of two children aged 14 and 18, has been selling food and drinks in Zanzibar since 2002. Her most popular items are juice, maize, and maandazi, which are small snacks composed of fried, semi-sweet dough, similar to plain donuts. She currently works in her shop from 8:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. everyday, earning a monthly profit of approximately $45.

Saida is now requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can purchase more ingredients to increase her maandazi output as well as additional stocks of juices and maize.

loans.use: To buy more ingredients for the maandazi that she cooks and sells.

loans.name: Ganijon

texts.ru:
Акбаров Ганиджон, 1979 года рождения, женат и у них 2 детей. У Ганиджона 6 лет опыта в этой деятельности. Он торгует на центральном рынке Гисара продуктами питания. В его ассортименте имеются разновидность конфет производства России, Ирана и Турции. Также в продаже имеются кондитерские изделия такие как печенье, пряники, халва, сахар и сушеные фрукты.   У Ганиджона небольшая лавка, но в дальнейшем хочет арендовать большое помещение для открытия продовольственного магазина. Покупает свой товар в кондитерских цехах и в оптовых магазинах Сафар – Центра. 
Ганиджону нужны средства для покупки халвы и сахара и он хочет получить займ в сумме 1000 сомони.
texts.en:
Ganijon A. was born in 1979, is married, and has two children. Ganijon has six years of sales experience. He sells food in Gissar’s central market. His inventory includes candy from Russia, Iran and Turkey. He also sells pastries such as cookies, ginger cakes, halva, sugar and dried fruit. Ganijon has a small stall, but in the future, he would like to rent a large place in order to open his own shop. He buys his goods in the confectionery shops in the wholesale shop Safar in the Shuhrat region. Ganijon needs to take out a loan to buy halva and sugar, and would like to borrow 1,000 somoni.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying halva and sugar

loans.name: Taifa

texts.en: Taifa, married with two children aged six and eight, has been selling food in Zanzibar for four years.  Working daily from 9:00 a.m. to 10:00 p.m., she earns a profit of approximately $100 each month.  Taifa is now requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy additional inventory for her shop, thereby increasing her sales and profits.

loans.use: To buy more food for her shop.

loans.name: Safinia

texts.en:
Safinia, 30 years old and divorced with two children, has been preparing and selling food in Zanzibar for seven years. She is currently able to earn approximately $20 each month and is now seeking her first loan so that she can buy more ingredients to increase her cooking capacity.

.

loans.use: To buy more ingredients for cooking and selling food.

loans.name: Ablaye

texts.fr: ABLAYE S. EST COMMERCANT DE DENREES ALIMENTAIRES DEPUIS SON ENFANCE. ACTUELLEMENT IL GERE SON PROPRE NEGOCE AU QUARTIER SOM A THIES. IL EST CELIBATAIRE SANS ENFANTS A CHARGE
texts.en:
ABLAYE S. has been a merchant of grocery items since he was a child. He currently has his own business in the SOM district in THIES. He is unmarried and has no children in his care.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To sell groceries

loans.name: Mabousso

texts.fr: MABOUSSO G. VEND DIVERS MATERIEL DE CONSTRUCTION AU MARCHE DE THIES DEPUIS 5 ANS. IL EST MARIE ET PERE DE 2 ENFANTS.
texts.en:
MABOUSSO G. has been selling various construction materials at the THIES marketplace for five years. He is married and the father of two children.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To sell construction material

loans.name: Dane

texts.fr: DANE S. VEND DES PRODUITS COSMETIQUES AU MARCHE DE GRAND THIES DEPUIS  06 ANS. IL HABITE AU QUARTIER CITE SENGHOR. IL EST CELIBATAIRE ET SANS ENFANTS A CHARGE.
texts.en:
DANE S. has been selling cosmetics at the GRAND THIES marketplace for six years. He lives in the CITE SENGHOR district. He is unmarried and has no children in his care.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To sell cosmetic products

loans.name: Jina

texts.en:
Jina has been selling dresses and fabric in Zanzibar for one year. She is currently able to earn a profit of approximately $85 each month through her sales. She is now requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can expand her inventory and increase her sales.

Jina is 23 years old, married, and has no children.

loans.use: To buy fabric and dresses

loans.name: Mzuri

texts.en:
Mzuri has been selling cooking pots, charcoal, vegetables, and palm leaves (used for weaving) at her shop in Zanzibar for ten years. She is currently able to earn a profit of approximately $45 each month. She is now requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she may buy more inventory for her shop and increase her profit.

Mzuri is 50 years old, and has one child and cares for two additional dependants.

loans.use: To buy more inventory for her shop.

loans.name: Tatu

texts.en:
Tatu, 45 years old and married with three grown children, has been selling cassava, potatoes, and other local foods since 2005, earning a profit of about $25 each month. Tatu is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania in order to buy more of these products to increase her sales and profit.

Cassava is eaten throughout the day in Tanzania, either as breakfast or a snack. The cassava is peeled and fried in oil, then topped off with salt. Potatoes are also a staple food as they are inexpensive and filling.

loans.use: To buy more foods to prepare and sell.

loans.name: Mwatum

texts.en:
Mwatum has been cooking and selling food in Zanzibar for 7 years. She is currently able to earn a profit of approximately $160 each month. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more ingredients to enable her to prepare a greater quantity of food and increase her profit.

Mwatum is 30 years old, married, and has no children.

loans.use: To buy more ingredients for the food that she cooks and sells.

loans.name: Maryan

texts.en: Maryan owns a small business in Zanzibar.  She is currently able to earn a profit of approximately $85 each month.  She is 30 years old, married, and has four children, aged 13, 12, 7, and 2-and-a-half.  She is hoping that her first loan from BRAC Tanzania will enable her to expand her business and increase her profit.

loans.use: To buy more inventory for her small business.

loans.name: Garden Of Hope Group

texts.en:
Garden of Hope is a support group based in Mombasa and affiliated to Coast General Hospital. It was formed by 15 members in 2008. Currently, membership has increased to 20. The group was formed with the following objectives:

1. Give moral and psychological support to members

2. Improve the welfare of members

3. Advocacy/speaking on issues affecting people living with HIV/Aids (PLWAs)

4. Advocating for economic empowerment of PLWAs.

Sixteen active members of the group have requested US $4000, each to receive US $250 to improve on their income generating activities as follows:

1. Rose N., who is 32 years old, needs the loan to buy poultry feed.

2. James M., a 43-year-old, runs a charcoal selling kiosk and needs a loan to increase stock of charcoal.

3. Jectone O., who is 37 years old, has applied for a loan to improve her cereal business.

4. Leornadus O., who is 36 years old and runs a food kiosk, requires the loan to buy stock of consumables for her food kiosk.

5. Zipporah K. is 28 years old. She requires the loan to increase her stock of new clothes for sale.

6. Joyce W. is 23 years old. She needs to buy stocks of rice for sale.

7. Metrice O. has applied for a loan to improve his tailoring business.

8. Joshua K., who runs retail kiosk, has applied for a loan to increase stock.

9. Jane W., a 23-year-old, needs the loan to improve her potato selling business

10. Webster I. is 34 years old and needs a loan to improve his vegetable stall business.

11. Mellin A. is 31 years old. She operates a telephone booth.

12. Joyce A. needs loan to increase her stock of charcoal.

13. Salim N. has applied for loan to buy stock of second hand clothes for sale.

14. Marren A., who runs a charcoal business, requires a loan to buy further stock of charcoal in bulk.

15. Meshack O. is the proprietor of a grocery stall. He has applied for a loan to improve his charcoal business.

16. Ruweda M. sells coconut products. She has applied for loan to boost her business.

loans.use: To improve and expand individual enterprises.

loans.name: Maryam

texts.en:
Maryam has been selling firewood in Zanzibar for three years. She works from 7:00am to 8:00pm every day and earns a profit of approximately $35 each month. She is now requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she may buy more inventory to increase her sales and profit.

Maryam is 35 years old, married, and has four chidlren, aged 1, 4, 13, and 14.

loans.use: To buy more firewood to sell.

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en: Joyce C. is married and has five children. She has received schooling through the senior high level. Joyce sells groceries like sugar, rice, biscuits, and soap at Kotokoraba in Cape Coast. She has been in this business since 1998. Her husband is a teacher. Joyce uses her income to support her husband in paying for food, shelter, and other family expenses. Joyce will use the loan to purchase a variety of groceries to meet the demand of her customers. She plans to reinvest the new profits in her business so she can increase her operations and, thereby, increase her income.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of groceries

loans.name: Aracely

texts.es:
Aracely inicio hace 4 años con el negocio porque le gusta la belleza y las ventas así que con el fin de apoyara su esposo con el gasto de la casa decidió vender primero como distribuidora independiente, después como sus ventas incrementaban inicio a 4 señoras las cuales también distribuyen los productos.

Ella necesita un préstamo por US $400 que pagara en 6 meses para invertir mas en el negocio para tener mejores oportunidades de venta y aprovecharlas ofertas de la compañía, así como seguir invirtiendo en sus consultoras de venta ya que hay que organizarles juntas y a veces por falta de capital no puede hacerlo.
texts.en:
Aracely started her business 4 years ago because she likes cosmetics and she enjoys sales. She needed to help her husband with the household expenses. She decided to start as an independent distributor and as her sales started improving she hired 4 other ladies to also work as distributors.

She requires a loan in the amount of $400 US, which will be repaid in a term of 4 months. She will invest the funds in the business to create better sales oppotunities and to take advantage of the special offers. She also wishes to keep investing on her hired help, to help keep the business well organized. Sometimes given the lack of capital funds she cannot keep up.


Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase merchandise.

loans.name: Bernarda

texts.es:
Bernarda inicio hace 3 años con el negocio porque en el habitacional donde vive sus vecinas y amigas se dedicaban a la venta de algún producto así que ella decidió vender perfumes con eso ayudaría a su marido con los gastos y tendría tiempo de cuidar a su hijo ya que cuando nació tuvo que dejar su empleo para atenderlo.

Ella necesita un préstamo por US $400 que pagara en 6 meses para poder instalar un local de perfumería en los mercados y vender no solo de catalogo, sino de marcas reconocidas las cuales solo maneja sobre pedido ya que son caras.
texts.en:
Three years ago Bernarda began her business because in the neighborhood where her neighbors and friends live, they sell one product or another, so she decided to sell perfume and in this way she would be able to help her husband with the expenses and have time to take care of her son because when he was born she had to leave her job to take care of him. She needs a loan for US$400, which will be repaid in 6 months, to be able to install a perfume locale in the markets and sell not only by catalog sales but also well known brands which she sells only by special order because they are expensive.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: open a locale in the market for her perfume business

loans.name: Felicia

texts.en:
Felicia A. sells clothing and fabrics at Kotokoraba in Cape Coast. Felicia has received primary education. She is married and has 1 child. Her husband is a mason. 

Felicia has been selling clothing and fabrics since 1999. She just introduced food items into her trade and they is doing well. She is responsible for helping her husband pay for school fees and other family expenses. 

Her loan will be used to buy more food and also sewing materials, clothing and fabrics. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to help her husband to build a house for their family.

loans.use: To buy more food and sewing materials, clothing and fabrics.

loans.name: Blanca Ludivina

texts.es:
Blanca inicio hace 5 años su negocio porque tenia que comprar calzado para sus hijos y se le hacia muy difícil comprarlo de contado ya que es muy caro así que decidió dedicarse a vender zapatos por catalogo, inicio ofreciéndolo sus vecinas y así se fue haciendo de clientes, ya que como tiene 4 hijos es difícil mantenerse con el sueldo de su marido el cual es muy variable ya que es comerciante en los mercados rodantes y en ocasiones por las lluvias o inclemencias del tiempo no le va bien con el negocio por lo cual decidió apoyarlo y para no descuidar a su hijo eligió el ramo de los zapatos en el cual le ha ido muy bien.

Ella necesita un préstamo por US $400 que pagara en 6 meses para invertir y tener mejores ventas. Con tu apoyo esto será posible.
texts.en:
Blanca started her business 5 years ago after she had to buy shoes for her children and found it difficult to buy them with cash because of the expense. That gave her the idea to buy shoes from catalogs and resell them. She started by offering her products to her neighbors who became her first customers. It's hard to support 4 children on her husband's income because he works as a merchant selling products in the region's temporary markets and his income is variable because of frequent bad weather. That's why Blanca decided to help her husband. In order not to disappoint her son she chose shoe sales, a business that has gone very well.

Blanca needs a US$400 loan, to be repaid in 6 months, to invest and increase sales. With your support, this will be possible.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy merchandise for resale.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose M. sells clothing for both ladies and gentlemen at Kotokoraba in Cape Coast. Rose has received a primary education. She is married and has 5 dependents. Her husband is on pension. Rose has been selling clothing since 1993. She is responsible for supporting her husband, paying for utility bills, and paying for other expenses of the family. Her loan will be used to increase her capital to buy more clothing for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to expand her capital base to increase her income to enable her to meet the basic needs of her family.

loans.use: Her loan will be used to increase her capital to buy more clothing for sale.

loans.name: Dora Alicia

texts.es:
Dora inicio hace 5 años con el negocio ya que no cuenta con el apoyo del papa de sus hijos para salir adelante con los gastos, y necesitaba dinero para la manutención de sus 2 hijos, así que decidió vender productos cosméticos por catalogo además hace manualidades en navidad, día de amor y la amistad, y otras fechas importantes, que también le ayudan con los ingresos familiares, como en esta compañía le dan oportunidad de pagar en un mes vende y luego recoge el dinero y paga las factura.

Ella necesita un préstamo por US $400 que pagara en 6 meses para hacer una inversión fuerte para comprar productos y hacer unas canastas con diversos productos para vender en navidad.
texts.en:
Dora started her business 5 years ago because she does not count on the support of her children’s father to pay for the household expenses. She needed money to support her 2 children, so she decided to sell cosmetics by catalogue. She also makes handicrafts, which further increase her income, for Christmas, Valentine’s Day, and other important holidays. Since this company gives her the chance to pay in one month, she sells products, then collects the money and pays for the orders.

She needs a loan of $400.00 USD, which will be repaid in 6 months, in order to invest in the purchase of products and make assorted gift baskets to sell during the Christmas season.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise

loans.name: Awa

texts.fr: Awa G. est mariée et mère de 02 enfants avec 2 autres à sa charge. Elle est membre du banc villageois de Pire Gourèye depuis 3 ans et demi. Son activité consiste à acheter et revendre des tissus teintés et tissus simples et des chaussures. Elle veut renforcer son commerce.  Le prêt qu’elle sollicite sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance.
texts.en:
Awa G. is married and the mother of two children plus two others in her care. She has been a member of the village loan group of Pire Gourèye for three and a half years. Her work consists of buying and selling dyed fabrics, plain cloth, and shoes. She wants to bolster her business. The loan she is requesting will be repaid all at once at the end of six months.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Commerce in cloth and shoes

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose A. sells food supplies including frozen fish. She buys the fresh fish from the fishermen and then keeps them in her cold store for her customers at Kotokoraba in Cape Coast to come and buy. Rose has received a junior high education. She is married and has 3 children. Her husband is a mason. Rose has been selling frozen fish since 1993. She is responsible for helping her husband pay for school fees and other family expenses. Her loan will be used to increase the quantity of fish she sells to meet the increase in demand and also to buy food supplies for resale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to expand her capital base to increase her income to enable her to meet the basic needs of her family.

loans.use: Her loan will be used to increase the quantity of fish she sells to meet the increase in demand and also to buy food supplies for resale.

loans.name: Sinignessigui (Prepare For The Future) Group

texts.fr:
Composé de six femmes de 38 ans, mariées et mères d’au moins 6 enfants, le groupe benkadi est spécialisé dans la restauration. Elles résident dans la sous préfecture de kimparana région de Ségou et sont des voisines de quartier. 
Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis deux ans. Le montant du prêt est passé de 50.000 FCFA au premier prêt à 150.000 FCFA pour le quatrième prêt. Elles sont toutes des restauratrices vu la situation géographique de leur village qui est un carrefour très fréquenté. Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter des sacs de riz, des seaux de pâte d’arachide et autres ingrédients alimentaires nécessaires dans la fabrication des plats. Les ventes sont effectuées sous des hangars au bord de la route traversant la localité à une clientèle constituée de voyageurs, routiers, chauffeurs et d’autochtones.
Elles comptent réaliser en moyenne 100 000 CFA. de bénéfice dont une partie sera utilisée pour faire face aux dépenses courantes de la famille et l’autre pour améliorer la présentation des restaurants.
texts.en:
Composed of six 38-year-old women, married and the mothers of at least 6 children, the Benkadi group is specialized in the restaurant business. They live in the Sous-prefecture of Kimparana, Ségou region, and are neighbors.

To expand the size of their businesses, the group members decided to join the loan program of Soro Yiriwaso two years ago. The amount they are allowed to borrow has gone from 50,000 F CFA for their first loan to 150,000 F CFA for their fourth. They are all engaged in food service due to the location of their village at a much-travelled crossroads. This loan will be used to buy sacks of rice, buckets of peanut butter, and other necessary ingredients for preparing their dishes. The sales are made out of open sheds along the road that passes through the village to a clientele consisting of travelers, transporters, drivers, and village people. They expect to make on average 100,000 CFA in profit of which a part will be used to cover daily household expenses and the rest to make their little restaurants look more presentable.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of ingredients for food service

loans.name: Maria Del Refugio

texts.es:
María inicio hace 3 años con el negocio en los mercados rodantes porque tenia L. necesidad D. apoyar a su marido con los gastos D. L. casa así que empezó vendiendo ropa D. elL. y D. su familia que le pasaban, ahora ya compra media paca cada mes y esto es lo que venD..

ElL. necesita un préstamo por US $ 400 que pagara en 6 meses para comprar una paca D. ropa completa para que el precio sea mas barato y así tener mejor venta, y también planea comprar una estructura para los tiempos en que hace lluvia o frio ya que L. que tiene es D. teL. y necesita una mas resistente.
texts.en:
María started her business 3 years ago in open-air markets because she needed to support her family with the household expenses. So, she began selling her own and her family's clothing that they gave her, and now purchases a and sells a half pack of clothing each month. María needs a $400 loan which she will repay in 6 months to purchase an entire pack of clothing so that the price will be lower and will therefore have greater sales. María also plans to purchase a structure so that she can continue selling in rain and cold, as her current shelter is maD. of cloth and is not resistant enough.

Translated from Spanish by Jordan Shanker, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase a pack of clothing and a rain shelter

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary A. is married and has 4 children. She has received schooling through primary education. Mary sells frozen chicken and other meat at Kotokoraba in Cape Coast, which she has done since 1998. Her husband is a fisherman. Mary uses her income to help her husband pay for school fees and other family expenses. Mary will use the loan to purchase more frozen meat for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Mary plans to expand the business and give her children a quality education.

loans.use: Mary will use the loan to purchase more frozen meat for sale.

loans.name: Maribel

texts.es:
Maribel inicio el negocio hace 4 años porque necesitaba ayudar a su marido en la economía familiar ya que el trabaja por su cuenta y en ocasiones no tiene trabajo, por lo cual ella ingreso con sus vecinas a la venta de ropa y con eso tiene un ingreso para cuando su esposo este sin trabajo no verse tan apretados económicamente.

Ella necesita un préstamo por US $400 que pagara en 6 meses para poder invertir en mas ropa para incrementar las ventas.
texts.en:
Maribel started her business four years ago becuase she neeeded to help her husband with family expenses. Her husband is only able to work occassionally, which is why she works with her neighbors selling clothing. With this work she has income for the times when her husband is without work so that they are not so squeezed economically. She needs a loan for $400, which she will repay in 6 months, in order to invest in more clothing so she can increase sales.


Translated from Spanish by Laura Jung, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To Purchase merchandise

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en: Since 1998, Rebecca E. has been selling clothing for both ladies and gentlemen at Kotokoraba in Cape Coast. Rebecca has received no formal education.  She is married and has three children. Her husband is a mechanic. She is responsible for helping her husband pay for the children's school fees, the utility bills, and other family expenses. She will use this loan to buy more clothing to sell. She hopes to increase her income so she can meet the basic needs of her family.

loans.use: To buy clothing

loans.name: Denis Alberto

texts.es: Denis habita en el barrio Jardines de Veracruz, tiene 43 años de edad, es soltero y tiene cuatros hijos de 3, 5, 6 y 8 años de edad. Don Denis es mecánico, tiene un pequeño negocio de venta de lubricantes, servicio de auto lavado. Tiene seis años de estar dedicándose a las ventasde estos productos, el negocio lo empezó de ahorros obtenidos de su actividad como mecánico y también con préstamos hechos a AFODENIC, con los cuales ha logrado mantenerse en el mercado. El préstamo solicitado es para invertir capital de trabajo, en la compra de lubricantes para ampliar su inventario. Sus planes futuros son seguir ampliando el negocio y brindar servicios integrales en el ramo automotriz.
texts.en:
Denis lives in the Jardines neighborhood of Veracruz, is 43 years old, single, and has four children ages 3, 5, 6 and 8. Denis is a mechanic, he has a small business selling lubricants and a car wash. He has had this business for 6 years, a business he began with savings from his work as a mechanic and also with loans from AFODENIC, with which he has been able to support himself in the market. The current loan is to invest it as working capital, buying lubricants to expand his inventory. His future plans are to continue expanding his business and providing needed automotive services.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy lubricants to expand his inventory

loans.name: Nohemi

texts.es:
Nohemí estudio cultora D. belleza y en su casa se dedica a cortar el pelo hacer faciales y algunos servicios D. belleza, las clientes le pedían que le recomendara cremas o cosas para su arreglo personal fue por eso que ella decidió vender por catalogo productos D. belleza, ya que no contaba con el dinero suficiente para establecer una estética, ya tiene 3 años en el negocio y le ha ido muy bien.

Ella necesita un préstamo por US $400 que pagara en 6 meses para comprar mas mercancía y tener que ofrecerle a sus clientas mas variedad, con las ganancias espera poder establecer su estética en un futuro cercano.
texts.en:
Nohemí studies cosmetology and runs a styling and beauty services business out of her home. Her clients ask her to reccomend cremes and other products to use themselves. As a result she decided to do catalog sales of beauty products, since she does not have enough capital to establish a salon. The business has done very well over the past three years. She needs a loan of $400 that she will repay in six months, so that she can purchase more merchandise and be able to offer her clients more variety. With the income she hopes to be able to establish a salon in the near future.


Translated from Spanish by Laura Jung, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purhcase merchandise

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en:
Comfort A. sells food items like beans and maize which are highly popular with Ghanaians at Kotokoraba in Cape Coast. She also prepares local dishes for sale at the market where she has a stall. Comfort has received primary education. She is married and has 3 children. Her husband is a merchant.

Comfort has been selling food items since 1998. She is responsible for helping her husband to meet the family’s financial needs. Her loan will be used to increase her capital to buy more foodstuffs for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to expand her capital base to increase her income to enable her to meet the basic needs of her family.

loans.use: to increase her capital to buy more foodstuffs for sale

loans.name: Norma Leticia

texts.es:
Norma inicio hace 3 años con el negocio porque le ayudaba a vender zapatos por catalogo a una vecina así que decidió mejor venderlos por su cuenta porque la vecina le pagaba el 10 % de cada par y vendiendo ella el porcentaje de ganancia es del 50% por lo que era un mejor negocio, ya que ya había hecho clientes y hasta la actualidad le va bien.

Ella necesita un préstamo por US $400 que pagara en 6 meses para invertir en mercancía y tener mejores ventas ya que desea poder tener un lugar en los mercados y así incrementar sus ventas.
texts.en:
Norma started the business three years ago because her neighbor was benefiting from selling shoes by catalog so she decided to sell them on her own because her neighbor was paying her 10% for each pair she sold and selling them directly she would make 50% so that was a better business. She already had her clients and up until now things have gone well. She needs a loan for $400, which she will repay in six months, to invest in merchandise and increase sales as she wants to have a place to sell in the markets.

Translated from Spanish by Hugh Yarbrough, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise

loans.name: Teriya (Friendship) Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Teriya est un regroupement de quatre femmes du village de kimparana (préfecture de San région de Ségou) qui sont des voisines de quartier. Elles ont en moyenne 30 ans, mariées et mères d’au moins 2 enfants.
Elles mènent une activité centrée autour du poisson qui est soit vendu frais, fumé ou grillé. Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis deux ans. Le montant du prêt est passé de 50.000 FCFA au premier prêt à 150.000 FCFA pour le cinquième prêt. Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour payer des cartons de poissons à partir de Mopti (Cinquième région du Mali). En plus de cette activité principale, certaines vendent du bois de chauffe.
Les produits sont vendus aux différentes foires de la zone ainsi qu’à la maison. Les femmes du groupe Teriya contribuent aux dépenses de la famille et injectent une partie des bénéfices dans leurs activités.
texts.en:
The Teriya goup is made up of 4 women from Kimparana village (San Prefecture, Ségou region) who are from the same neighborhood. They are on average 30, married, and have at least 2 children.

Their principal business revolves around fish which is sold either fresh, smoked, or grilled. To expand the size of their businesses, the members of the group decided two years ago to join the credit program of Soro Yiriwaso. The amount of money they were allowed to borrow started off at 50,000 F CFA for their first loan and is now at 150,000 F CFA for their 5th loan. This loan will be used to buy cases of fish from Mopti (fifth region of Mali). Besides this primary business, some of the members of the group sell firewood.

Their products are sold at the various marketdays in the area as well as out of their houses. The women of the Teriya group help to cover family expenses and invest a part of the profit back into their businesses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of fish for re-sale

loans.name: Cheikh

texts.fr:
Cheikh S. tient une quicqillerie sur le boulevard 54m au quartier de Tiléne. Avec la vente des piéces détachées il arrive à faire vivre son épouse et ses 3 enfants.
Il sollicite ce prêt pour renforcer son commerce et gagner davantage de profits.
texts.en:
Cheikh S. has a hardware shop on the Boulevard 54m in the suburb of Tiléne. With the sale of spare parts, he manages to support his wife and his three children.

He is requesting this loan to bolster his business and make more profit.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: expand his hardware business
